But... how?

Your code is completely wrong. How can it have passed the example strings? Must have been some very unlucky examples, then!

for (int j = 0; j < 3; j++) {//Count 3 chars at once
  sequence += S.charAt(i);//Add said Chars to our sequence
 }

This will add the exact same character, 3 times. i never changes. Thus, sequence is either "..." or "XXX".

if (sequence.contains("X")) {//Check for potholes
  fixes++;//We can fix everything in this sequence
  sequence = "";//reset our sequence
}

This boils down to: If it was "XXX", increment fixes.

if (sequence.contains("X")) {//Check anything left, since not all roads are multiples of 3
               fixes++;
           }

This if cannot possibly trigger. Think about it.

All your code does, is count potholes. In a convoluted way.

I thought this was good enough for what was asked

You've made 3 major errors. Each is individually probably sufficient to get a significant downgrade if this is an exercise for a job:

  • The code contains a performance faux-pas (concatenating strings using + in a loop), when the question explicitly calls out that performance is important. You'd have to call it out and explain why you intentionally broke a rule of thumb, at least.

  • The code straight up doesn't work, at all.

  • Even if you fix it, the code STILL does not work. Take, for example, the input ".X.X..". The correct answer is 1. Even if you fixed your code and you treat each chunk of 3 properly (instead of one at a time due to your messup between j and i), your algorithm returns 2. The question is a little more complicated than you think it is. Not much, mind. Still, the entire algorithm as written should just be tossed in the bin, and start over. Don't start with programming. Start with schetching out the problem and considering the algorithm required. Only then start coding.

Here is the correct algorithm. Just sketched out, thinking the problem through:

Just scan for a pothole. Once you find one, fix it and skip past the next 2 units of road while you're at it. They just do not matter. If they have potholes, we'll fix em for free along with the hole we found.

That's all you need to do. Just count potholes, ignoring any potholes that are 1 or 2 'to the right' of a pothole we fixed.

Here:

public int solution(String s) {
  int holes = 0;
  for (int i = 0; i < s.length(); i++)
    if (s.charAt(i) == 'X') {
      holes++;
      i += 2;
    }
  }
  return holes;
}

This code is much simpler, is correct, and is clearly as fast as it's ever gonna get.

answers.title: Pothole fixing machine
answers.body:
def pothole_fixing(road):
    potholes = 0
    sections = 0
    for i in range(len(road)):
        if road[i] == 'X':
            potholes += 1
        else:
            if potholes > 0:
                sections += -(-potholes // 3)
                potholes = 0
              
    if potholes > 0:
        sections += -(-potholes // 3)
    return(sections)

The function takes a string road representing the road with potholes and returns the minimum number of sections needed to fix all potholes.

answers.title: Pothole fixing machine
answers.body:
public static int solution2(String s) {
    int patchCount = 0;
    int i = 0;
    while(i<s.length()){
        if(s.charAt(i)=='X'){
            patchCount ++;
            i += 3-i%3;
        } else {
            i++;
        }
    }
    return patchCount;
}

items.title: Pothole fixing machine
items.body:
I recently worked on an online problem for which answers were not provided, however, I would like to know where I went wrong. The prompt was strange, but I will do my best to explain it:

There is a machine that can fix all potholes along a road 3 units in length. A unit of Road will be represented with a period in a String. For example, "..." = one section of road 3 units in length. Potholes are marked with an "X" in the road, and also count as a unit of length. The task is to take a road of length N and fix all potholes with the fewest possible sections repaired by the machine. This problem is concerned with performance over correctness.

  • Example 1: A road represented by ".X." would require 1 fix.
  • Example 2: A road represented by "..X...X" would require 2 fixes.
  • Example 3: A road represented by "XXX.XXXX" would require 3 fixes.

My approach (shown below) was to count sections of String in increments of 3 chars at once. If that sequence contained an "X", then it needed a fix and vice versa. To account for roads that aren't multiples of 3 in length I just kept the sequence reading and checked whatever was left. I'm also not sure how to make the program better for performance (other than replacing my sequence String with a StringBuilder)

public class Solution {
//Note: I had to re-write this from memory, as I was not given it back by the online problem checker
    public int solution(String S) {
        int fixes = 0;
        String sequence = "";//Perhaps use StringBuilder?
        for (int i = 0; i < S.length(); i++) {//read the entire incoming string
            for (int j = 0; j < 3; j++) {//Count 3 chars at once
                sequence += S.charAt(i);//Add said Chars to our sequence
            }
            if (sequence.contains("X")) {//Check for potholes
                fixes++;//We can fix everything in this sequence
                sequence = "";//reset our sequence
            }
        }
        if (sequence.contains("X")) {//Check anything left, since not all roads are multiples of 3
                fixes++;
            }
        return fixes;
    }
}

I thought this was good enough for what was asked, and it passed all of the given example Strings, but apparently failed horribly upon review. I don't know what I've done wrong, though I feel like there's probably something small and stupid that I'm missing.

UPDATE:

I was indeed missing something obvious, I need to start reading at the first "X", something like this:

        if (S.charAt(i) == 'X') {//Start counting at the first X
            for (int j = 0; j < 3; j++) {//Count 3 chars at once
                if (i + j <= S.length() - 1) {//no outofbounds exceptions please!
                    sequence += S.charAt(i + j);//Add said Chars to our sequence
                }
            }
        }

Now I just need to make sure it meets performance requirements.

answers.title: Identifying method reference to a non static java method represented as Bi-function
answers.body:
You are not supposed to know what method a method reference is referencing. If there is a way (and I doubt that), it would be implementation dependent.

The way that method references are implemented, is that they evaluate to an instance of a hidden class, This hidden class is generated at runtime, and would implement the functional interface.

Suppose you have

BiFunction<Abc, Input1, Input2> f = Abc::method1;

this would create a hidden class with apply implemented like this:

public Object apply(Object a, Object b) {
    ((Abc)a).method1((Input1)b);
}
// of course, the runtime wouldn't generate Java source code - this is for demonstration only

Note that the generic parameters are all erased.

To find out which method the method reference is referencing at runtime, you would need to go into the implementation of the apply method in the hidden class to find out. You might be able to write the hidden class to a .class file (honestly I'm not even sure if this is possible), then read that file to find how the apply method is implemented.

Another attempt at trying to get the parameter types would be try to getGenericInterfaces of the hidden class, then use getActualTypeArguments to find out the second type argument of BiFunction. Whether this would work would depend on whether the implementation of the JVM inserts generic type information into the generated hidden class, and I've never seen any implementation do this.

If you just want to accept a fixed set of method references, I would suggest using an enum to represent that set of methods, and switch on the enum in testSuccess and call those methods.

If you want to accept any one-argument method on Abc, you would need a an object that not only wraps the method, but also the type of the argument it takes, e.g.:

abstract class MethodOfAbc {
    private final Class<?> parameterType;
    public abstract Object apply(Abc abc, Object o);

    // optionally,
    // private String methodName;
    
    public MethodOfAbc(Class<?> parameterType) {
        this.parameterType = parameterType;
    }
    public Class<?> getParameterType() { return parameterType; }
    public static <T, U> MethodOfAbc make(BiFunction<Abc, T, U> f, Class<T> parameterType) {
        return new MethodOfAbc(parameterType) {
            @Override
            public Object apply(Abc abc, Object o) {
                return f.apply(abc, (T)o);
            }
        };
    }
}

// Usage:
testSuccess(MethodOfAbc.make(Abc::method1, Input1.class));

Now you can check the type by inspecting getParameterType(), and deciding the input.

answers.title: Spring RestTemplate: How to reach state to check #is4xxClientError, instead of RestClientException 1st?
answers.body:
RestTemplate has a method

public void setErrorHandler(ResponseErrorHandler errorHandler);

And ResponseErrorHandler interface look like this.

public interface ResponseErrorHandler {

    boolean hasError(ClientHttpResponse response) throws IOException;

    void handleError(ClientHttpResponse response) throws IOException;
}

Whenever RestTemplate processes a response, it first call ResponseErrorHandler#hasError(), if it returns true, ResponseErrorHandler#handleError() is called which may throw exception.

If you don't set ResponseErrorHandler#setErrorHandler(), it defaults to DefaultResponseErrorHandler.java.
Default implementation treats 4xx / 5xx series status code as error and throws RestClientException (not this exception but subclasses of this exception).

You can always write your own ResponseErrorHandler and override the default behavior. So this way you can get a ResponseEntity object even in case of 4xx / 5xx (by writing your own implementation of ResponseErrorHandler and returning always false from the method hasError()).

Once you have ResponseEntity object, you can use ResponseEntity#getStatusCode()#is4xxClientError() method for the same purpose.

I don't understand why `HttpStatus#is4xxClientError` even exists if instead an `Exception` is thrown that prevents returning a `ResponseEntity` with `HttpStatus` to call #`is4xxClientError` on... 

I'm reasonably convinced what I just described is the actual situation, because I can find other accounts on the internet that confirm that (i.e: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/16194014/spring-mvc-resttemplate-launch-exception-when-http-404-happens/).

answers.title: Java/FX and Scenebuilder; collision detection and stopping movement
answers.body:
Try breaking out the loop once a collision is detected.

public boolean checkCollisionUnbreakables(Player player, ArrayList<Rectangle> unbreakableObjects) {
    Bounds playerBounds = player.getPlayerBounds();
    Boolean collide = false;
    for (Rectangle rectangle : unbreakableObjects) {
            
        Bounds rectangleBounds = rectangle.getBoundsInParent();

        if (playerBounds.intersects(rectangleBounds)) {
            System.out.println("You can't go there!");
            collide = true;break;
        } 
    }
    return collide;
}

Your loop still continues to iterate through all the unbreakable objects and will return false if that unbreakable object isn't within the player bounds. Sure it will print out the warning but you didn't break the loop, resulting it to return all iterated results.

answers.title: Java/FX and Scenebuilder; collision detection and stopping movement
answers.body:
I saw some problems in your code.

1- In your Player class, the AnimationTimer updates the value of X and Y without checking with Collision Handler if it is allowed. So, it will get moving independently of any check. Create an atribute like "layoutX" and update it in Player, to separate the intended position and the actual position.

    AnimationTimer timer = new AnimationTimer() {
//      double currentX = player.getLayoutX();
//      double currentY = player.getLayoutY();
//      
        @Override
        public void handle(long timestamp) {
//          double currentX = player.getLayoutX();
//          double currrentY = player.getLayoutY();
            if(upPressed.get()) {
                player.setLayoutY(player.getLayoutY() - movementVariable);
            }
            if(downPressed.get()){
                player.setLayoutY(player.getLayoutY() + movementVariable);
            }
            if(leftPressed.get()){
                player.setLayoutX(player.getLayoutX() - movementVariable);
            }
            if(rightPressed.get()){
                player.setLayoutX(player.getLayoutX() + movementVariable);
            }
            
        }
    };

2- Change your PlayerController to something like that:

@Override
public void initialize(URL arg0, ResourceBundle arg1) {
    this.scene = scene;
    playerComponent = new Player(player, x, y, lives, scoreCounter);        
    gameLoop = new AnimationTimer() {

        @Override
        public void handle(long arg0) {
            double currentX = player.getLayoutX();
            double currentY = player.getLayoutY();
            
            playerComponent.makeMovable(player, scene, unbreakableObjects);
            if(!collisionHandler.checkCollisionUnbreakables(playerComponent, unbreakableObjects)) {
                player.setX(currentX);
                player.setY(currentY);
            }
        
        }   
    };

So, separating x and layoutX will let you do the getLayoutX (the intended position). You also should put a negation "!" in the if, because you need to move when there is not an unbreakable, not when there is one.

I created a collision detection method that returns true when the player encounters an unbreakable wall and prints out that there is a collision, but the player continues moving over it. This is my player class

package application;

import java.util.ArrayList;

import javafx.animation.AnimationTimer;
import javafx.beans.binding.BooleanBinding;
import javafx.beans.property.BooleanProperty;
import javafx.beans.property.SimpleBooleanProperty;
import javafx.fxml.FXML;
import javafx.geometry.Bounds;
import javafx.scene.image.ImageView;
import javafx.scene.input.KeyCode;
import javafx.scene.input.KeyEvent;
import javafx.scene.layout.AnchorPane;
import javafx.scene.shape.Rectangle;

public class Player{
    @FXML private ImageView player;
    @FXML AnchorPane scene;
    private double x;
    private double y;
    private int lives;
    private int scoreCounter;
    private BooleanProperty upPressed = new SimpleBooleanProperty();
    private BooleanProperty leftPressed = new SimpleBooleanProperty();
    private BooleanProperty rightPressed = new SimpleBooleanProperty();
    private BooleanProperty downPressed = new SimpleBooleanProperty();
    
    private BooleanBinding keyPressed = upPressed.or(leftPressed).or(rightPressed).or(downPressed);
    
    private boolean left, up, right, down;
    boolean canMove = true;
    
    private double movementVariable = 0.75;
    
    CollisionHandler collisionHandler = new CollisionHandler();

        
    public Player(ImageView player, double x, double y, int lives, int scoreCounter) {
        this.player = player;
        this.x = x;
        this.y = y;
        this.lives = lives;
        this.scoreCounter = scoreCounter;
    }
    
 
    public void makeMovable(ImageView player, AnchorPane scene, ArrayList<Rectangle> unbreakableObjects) {
        this.player = player;
        this.scene = scene;
        
        movementSetup();
        
        keyPressed.addListener(((observableValue, aBoolean, t1) -> {
            if (!aBoolean) {
                timer.start();
                canMove = false;
            } else {
                timer.stop();
            }
        }));
    }
    
    AnimationTimer timer = new AnimationTimer() {
//      double currentX = player.getLayoutX();
//      double currentY = player.getLayoutY();
//      
        @Override
        public void handle(long timestamp) {
//          double currentX = player.getLayoutX();
//          double currrentY = player.getLayoutY();
            if(upPressed.get()) {
                player.setLayoutY(player.getLayoutY() - movementVariable);
            }
            if(downPressed.get()){
                player.setLayoutY(player.getLayoutY() + movementVariable);
            }
            if(leftPressed.get()){
                player.setLayoutX(player.getLayoutX() - movementVariable);
            }
            if(rightPressed.get()){
                player.setLayoutX(player.getLayoutX() + movementVariable);
            }
            
        }
    };
    
    public boolean playerCollidesWithUnbreakable(double x, double y, ArrayList <Rectangle> unbreakables) {
        if (collisionHandler.checkCollisionUnbreakables(this, unbreakables)) {
            if(upPressed.get()) {
                player.setLayoutY(player.getLayoutY() + movementVariable);
            }
            if(downPressed.get()){
                player.setLayoutY(player.getLayoutY() - movementVariable);
            }
            if(leftPressed.get()){
                player.setLayoutX(player.getLayoutX() + movementVariable);
            }
            if(rightPressed.get()){
                player.setLayoutX(player.getLayoutX() - movementVariable);
            }
                return true;
            } else {
                return false;
            }
    }
    
    private void movementSetup(){
        scene.setOnKeyPressed(e -> {
            if(e.getCode() == KeyCode.W) {
                upPressed.set(true);
                up = true;
            }
            if(e.getCode() == KeyCode.A) {
                leftPressed.set(true);
                left = true;
            }
            if(e.getCode() == KeyCode.S) {
                downPressed.set(true);
                down = true;
            }
            if(e.getCode() == KeyCode.D) {
                rightPressed.set(true);
                right = true;
            }
        });
        scene.setOnKeyReleased(e ->{
            if(e.getCode() == KeyCode.W) {
                upPressed.set(false);
                up = true;
            }
            if(e.getCode() == KeyCode.A) {
                leftPressed.set(false);
                left = true;
            }
            if(e.getCode() == KeyCode.S) {
                downPressed.set(false);
                down = true;
            }
            if(e.getCode() == KeyCode.D) {
                rightPressed.set(false);
                right = true;
            }
        });
    }
    public int getScore() {
            return this.scoreCounter;
    }
    
    public void incrementScore() {
            this.scoreCounter++;
    }
    
    public double returnX() {
            return player.getX();
    }
    
    public double returnY() {
            return player.getY();
    }
    
    public void newX(double x) {
            player.setX(x);
    }
    
    public void newY(double y) {
            player.setY(y);
    }
    
    public Bounds getPlayerBounds() {
        return player.getBoundsInParent();
    }

  
    public ImageView getPlayerImageView() {
        return player;
    }

}

package application;

import java.util.ArrayList;

public class CollisionHandler {
    public boolean checkCollisionUnbreakables(Player player, ArrayList<Rectangle> unbreakableObjects) {
        Bounds playerBounds = player.getPlayerBounds();
        
        for (Rectangle rectangle : unbreakableObjects) {
                
            Bounds rectangleBounds = rectangle.getBoundsInParent();

            if (playerBounds.intersects(rectangleBounds)) {
                System.out.println("You can't go there!");
                return true;
            } 
        }
        return false;
    }
    public boolean checkCollisionBreakables(Player player, ArrayList<ImageView> breakableObjects) {
        Bounds playerBounds = player.getPlayerBounds();
        
        for (ImageView breakable : breakableObjects) {
            Bounds breakableBounds = breakable.getBoundsInParent();
            if (playerBounds.intersects(breakableBounds)) {
                if (breakable.getImage() == null) {
//                  System.out.println("Cleared already");
                    // Cleared already
                    return false;
                } else {

                    System.out.println("Picked up trash");
                breakable.setImage(null);
                return true;
                }
            }
        }
        return false;
    }
}

answers.title: Parsing Python code using ANTLR in Java with gradle
answers.body:
You do not need to run transformGrammar.py. That is only needed if you are going to use Python as the target language (Java is your target language).

To parse a python source file in Java and print the function names inside the .py file, do the following:

1. download files

Create a directory and download the following files:

wget https://www.antlr.org/download/antlr-4.13.1-complete.jar
wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/antlr/grammars-v4/master/python/python3/Python3Lexer.g4
wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/antlr/grammars-v4/master/python/python3/Python3Parser.g4
wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/antlr/grammars-v4/master/python/python3/Java/Python3LexerBase.java
wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/antlr/grammars-v4/master/python/python3/Java/Python3ParserBase.java

(I used the command line wget, but you can simply download them through your browser too)

2. main class

In that same directory, create a file called Main.java with the following contents:

import org.antlr.v4.runtime.*;
import org.antlr.v4.runtime.tree.*;

public class Main {

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        
        String source = "def foo():\n    pass\n\ndef quared(n):\n    return n * n";

        System.out.println(source + "\n");
        
        Python3Lexer lexer = new Python3Lexer(CharStreams.fromString(source));
        Python3Parser parser = new Python3Parser(new CommonTokenStream(lexer));

        ParseTreeWalker.DEFAULT.walk(new Python3ParserBaseListener() {

            // funcdef
            //  : 'def' name parameters ('->' test)? ':' block
            //  ;
            @Override
            public void enterFuncdef(Python3Parser.FuncdefContext ctx) {
                System.out.println("name=" + ctx.name().getText());
            }

        }, parser.file_input());
    }
}

3. generate parser

To generate the lexer and parser classes, execute the following command:

java -jar antlr-4.13.1-complete.jar *.g4

4. compile java

To compile all Java source files, execute the following command:

javac -cp antlr-4.13.1-complete.jar *.java

5. run main class

To run the Main class, execute the following command when you're on Linux or Mac:

java -cp .:antlr-4.13.1-complete.jar Main

On Windows do:

java -cp .;antlr-4.13.1-complete.jar Main

You should see the following being printed to your console:

def foo():
    pass

def quared(n):
    return n * n

name=foo
name=quared

items.title: Parsing Python code using ANTLR in Java with gradle
items.body:
Context

I am trying to parse some Python code, and find a function inside a .py file using ANTLR. However I am experiencing some difficulties understanding how to use ANTLR within java.

build.gradle

The following build.gradle file content is used to include ANTLR:

plugins {
    ...

    // Allow using antler.
    id 'antlr'
}

dependencies {
...

    // Include support for ANTLR runtime dependency.
    implementation 'org.antlr:antlr4-runtime:4.13.1'

    }

And based on this example 1 I have included the files: Python3Parser.g4 and Python3Lexer.g4 files in the same directory as the EditPython.java file below. And based on this example 2 I included the Python3LexerBase.java and Python3ParserBase.java (which I believe eventually yield the Python3Lexer.g4 and Python3Parser.g4 files when one runs:

python transformGrammar.py
antlr4 -Dlanguage=Python3 -o gen *.g4

MWE

This is a minimal class that tries to use the Python3Parser object.

import org.antlr.v4.runtime.CommonTokenStream;
import org.antlr.v4.runtime.tree.ParseTree;
import org.antlr.v4.runtime.tree.TerminalNode;

public class EditPython {

  public static void main(String[] args) {
    if (args.length == 0) {
      System.out.println("Please provide a Python code snippet as an argument.");
      return;
    }

    String pythonCode = args[0];
    modifyFunctionDocumentation(pythonCode);
  }

  public static void modifyFunctionDocumentation(String pythonCode) {
    // Parse Python code to get the tree
    Python3Lexer lexer = new Python3Lexer(CharStreams.fromString(pythonCode));
    CommonTokenStream tokens = new CommonTokenStream(lexer);
    Python3Parser parser = new Python3Parser(tokens);
    ParseTree tree = parser.file_input();

    // Traverse the tree to find and modify documentation
    Python3Parser.File_inputContext ctx = parser.file_input();
    Python3Parser.StmtContext stmtContext = ctx.stmt(0); // Assuming it's the first statement
    if (stmtContext.funcdef() != null && stmtContext.funcdef().NAME().getText().equals("some_function")) {
      // Assuming docstring is represented as STRING() in AST
      Python3Parser.FuncdefContext funcDefContext = stmtContext.funcdef();
      TerminalNode stringNode = funcDefContext.STRING();
      if (stringNode != null) {
        String docstring = stringNode.getText();
        System.out.println("Found the function: some_function");
        System.out.println("Docstring: " + docstring);
      } else {
        System.out.println("Function some_function found, but no docstring.");
      }
    } else {
      System.out.println("Function some_function not found in the provided code.");
    }
  }
}

Issue

However when I compile it, it returns:

                                ^
EditPython.java:20: error: cannot find symbol
    Python3Lexer lexer = new Python3Lexer(CharStreams.fromString(pythonCode));
    ^

Because I did not import Python3Lexer. However when I do com.someproject.somefolder.Python3Lexer, it says:

EditPython.java:5: error: cannot find symbol
import com.someproject.somefolder.Python3Lexer;
                                  ^

Because the Python3Lexer.g4 file is not a Python3Lexer.java file.

Question

How can I include the Python3Lexer file in the Java code such that I can use the Python3Parser object?

answers.body_markdown:
> `javac src/main/*.java -d classes`

This asks your OS to enumerate every file that matches the `*.java` glob in the `src/main` directory. So, this __does not include, for example, `src/main/temporarystorage/Station.java`__. Because that's not how your OS globber works, and there is no simple way to say; "List every file ending in java in this dir _and every subdir of this dir_".

Thus, no wonder it can't find Station.java. How could it?

## Solution 1: List em

```bash
javac src/main/*.java src/main/temporarystorage/*.java ––– -d classes
```

Will work, if you add each and every subdir at the long dash. Yes, every time you add a package you'll have to remember to add it to this `javac` command, at which point you might be thinking about making a shell script, or even using `find` or `dir /s` or similar shenanigans to automate the process.

Congratulations!!! You're writing a build system! However, some pretty good ones exist, don't reinvent stuff unneccessarily:

## Solution 2: Use a build system

This is where 99% of all non-academic java projects end up. You use for example [Maven](https://maven.apache.org), which does know that every java source file in every subdir all needs to be compiled. You'll have to read the tutorial. A ton of em exist, it's a fairly popular build system. There are many alternatives if you don't like it. For example, gradle. Or ant.

## Solution 3: `-sourcepath` hackery

You can attempt this:

```bash
javac -sourcepath src/main -d classes src/main/*.java
```

This has some downsides. In particular, this doesn't actually compile stuff unless it is needed, which sounds great, but you end up with lots of new 'main roots' in real apps (plugin architecture, logback endpoints, HTML handle endpoints, the list is long), so that's generally not good (that command will not compile _every java file in this dir and every subdir_, it merely compiles the java files in this dir, but if it compiling it needs some other java file to be compiled, it'll be found and compiled).

I don't recommend this long term.

## So what should I do?

Solution 2. Use a build system. At least, ASAP. For this academic project you might just want to scoot by with the `-sourcepath` hack and if that doesn't work, explicit listing. But, know that no 'real' (actual euros or eyeballs interested in) java project does that.

items.body:
When using VSCode we have 0 errors and our only warnings are "x is never used" (either because it's unfinished portions or because we put redundant imports).

But when we try to compile classes, we get several errors saying symbols or packages aren't found or do not exist. (see below)

I think the main issues are "package storage does not exist" and "package vehicle does not exist". After solving those, I think everything should click back into place.

I'm sure it's something dumb like syntax or folder placement but we could not solve it.

The two suggestions I got until the former post got deleted were :

<< Make the "private ControlCenter" part of the code public >>

As long as the class itself is public I don't think the problem comes from there. We're using the "singleton" design pattern for ControlCenter, so its has a private constructor because we're using the Singleton design for it.

​

<< Pay attention to uppercase vs lowercase >>

I renamed every package that used PascalCase into all-lowercase, and every class has its name in PascalCase. But even after that the problems subsist.

comments.body_markdown: If I'm not mistaken, iOS puts all commands/requests in a single fifo queue. A bunch of Write Without Response directly after each other will be fast but requests with response take longer time since it needs to wait for the response. That will hold up your writes without response. You can lower the connection interval to speed up each round trip. But otherwise I suggest you to use notifications in the other direction.

items.body_markdown:
I have a project with a friend, where we want to remote control our Java program on a Raspi with an IPhone via BLE. Therefore, I code the Raspi side in Java, using BlueZ over DBus, my friend codes the IPhone side using Swift and the Corebluetooth library. For both of us this is our first time doing a project with bluetooth.

Anyway, I open a peripheral GATT server on the Raspi, setting all the services and characteristrics we need, as well as their flags. But we discovered some weird behaviour upon the actual data exchange. Our idea is that every x milliseconds, the IPhone issues one cycle of all read/write-without-response requests for all characteristics successively, where x is a variable we set at compile time and figure out by trying. We tried 100ms, 500ms and 1000ms, and the result was always the same: the first request in the cycle reached my program every x+250ms, +- 50ms. BUT no request was ever lost, they just arrived consistently slower, as if buffered in some FIFO-queue that was filled faster that emptied. BUT, if we disable all read requests, then all write requests arrive at the expected rate.

Since then we tried to figure out why this happens, and especially if it happens on the IPhone or Raspi side. I traced the blutooth packages with btmon on the Raspi, and it shows the same timestamps as in my logs, therefore my code can't be the problem. The the remaining faults can be either BlueZ on the Raspi side, or Corebluetooth on the IPhone side.

We are working on setting up a packet tracer on the IPhone. But until we figure that out, I figured I could also ask here if anyone happens to have experience with BLE and has any suspicion of what is happening here, why it is happening, or on which side it happens, and what else we could try to trace the error. Sadly, there is not much BlueZ documentation on the internet.

Therefore, I code the Raspi side in Java, using BlueZ over DBus, my friend codes the IPhone side using Swift and the Corebluetooth library. For both of us this is our first time doing a project with bluetooth.

Anyway, I open a peripheral GATT server on the Raspi, setting all the services and characteristrics we need, as well as their flags. But we discovered some weird behaviour upon the actual data exchange. Our idea is that every x milliseconds, the IPhone issues one cycle of all read/write-without-response requests for all characteristics successively, where x is a variable we set at compile time and figure out by trying. We tried 100ms, 500ms and 1000ms, and the result was always the same: the first request in the cycle reached my program every x+250ms, +- 50ms. BUT no request was ever lost, they just arrived consistently slower, as if buffered in some FIFO-queue that was filled faster that emptied. BUT, if we disable all read requests, then all write requests arrive at the expected rate.

Since then we tried to figure out why this happens, and especially if it happens on the IPhone or Raspi side. I traced the blutooth packages with btmon on the Raspi, and it shows the same timestamps as in my logs, therefore my code can't be the problem. The the remaining faults can be either BlueZ on the Raspi side, or Corebluetooth on the IPhone side.

We are working on setting up a packet tracer on the IPhone. But until we figure that out, I figured I could also ask here if anyone happens to have experience with BLE and has any suspicion of what is happening here, why it is happening, or on which side it happens, and what else we could try to trace the error. items.title: Pause, Start, Stop java
items.body:
I have code that takes an image, extracts the text, and then reads it out. I want it to pause start and stop when the user hits the button. I have a stop and start feature, but when I hit stop, and it goes to continue, it restarts from the beginning.

Is there any way to track where the reader is on when it is reading the text to make sure that it continues from where it left off?

Recognizing Text Code:

private void recognizedTextFromImage() {
    Log.d(TAG, "recognizedTextFromImage: ");
    try {
        InputImage inputImage = InputImage.fromFilePath(this, imageUri);

        textRecognizer.process(inputImage)
                .addOnSuccessListener(text -> {
                    String recognizedText = text.getText();
                    recognizedTextEt.setText(recognizedText);

                    // Speak the recognized text
                    spokenText = text.getText();
                    recognizedTextEt.setText(spokenText);

                    speakRecognizedText();
                })
                .addOnFailureListener(e -> {
                    Log.e(TAG, "onFailure: ", e);
                    Toast.makeText(MainActivity.this, "Failed recognizing text due to " + e.getMessage(), Toast.LENGTH_SHORT).show();
                });
    } catch (Exception e) {
        Log.e(TAG, "recognizedTextFromImage: ", e);
        Toast.makeText(MainActivity.this, "Failed Preparing Image due to " + e.getMessage(), Toast.LENGTH_SHORT).show();
    }
}

Stop, Start, Continue:

private void speakRecognizedText() {
    if (textToSpeech != null && textToSpeech.getEngines().size() > 0) {
        isSpeaking = false;
        startStopContinueSpeechBtn.setText("Start");

        if (lastPosition == 0) {
            Toast.makeText(this, "Press 'Start' to start listening", Toast.LENGTH_SHORT).show();
        } else {
            String text = spokenText.substring(lastPosition);
        }
    }
}

private void stopSpeech() {
    if (textToSpeech != null) {
        lastPosition = textToSpeech.stop();
        isSpeaking = false;
        isPaused = true;
        startStopContinueSpeechBtn.setText("Continue");
    }
}

private void continueSpeech() {
    if (textToSpeech != null && !isSpeaking) {
        isSpeaking = true;
        isPaused = false;
        startStopContinueSpeechBtn.setText("Stop");

        String text = spokenText.substring(lastPosition);
        textToSpeech.speak(text, TextToSpeech.QUEUE_ADD, null, text);
    }
}


private void startSpeech() {
    if (textToSpeech != null) {
        String text = recognizedTextEt.getText().toString();
        if (!text.isEmpty()) {
            isSpeaking = true;
            isPaused = false;
            textToSpeech.speak(text, TextToSpeech.QUEUE_FLUSH, null, text);
            startStopContinueSpeechBtn.setText("Stop");
        }
    }
}

answers.body_markdown:
If you add `@JsonIgnore` annotation on property `private Set<Account> accounts` will remove that object from response.

When spring return response it will try to convert entity object into JSON object. So it will convert parent its child in to JSON so it will fetch all the child object and convert into JSON. It will also keep hibernate session open until the response send.

You should not expose Entity object directy in response. Instead convert them to DTO/VO object and return from response. Checkout https://stackoverflow.com/questions/73921071/adding-fields-to-an-object-returned-by-spring-data-rest-endpoint/74037643#74037643

The VO/DTO will give you total control what you want to expose in API and also reduce overhead of hibernate.

answers.title: spring boot hibernate, how to avoid returning all the child objects?
answers.body:
Even though the lazy fetch type is specified for associated entities, the entire Customer object is returned from the endpoint, leading to the initialization of lazy-loaded fields during serialization.

You can use projections, to retrieve only needed properties, since Spring Data allows modeling dedicated return types, to more selectively retrieve partial views of the managed aggregates.

For each response type, it's preferable to provide a separate endpoint. For example, to provide an endpoint for returning a customer with accounts, you can do the following.

First, declare an interface projection that exposes accessor methods for the properties to be read.

public interface CustomerWithAccountsProjection {
  String getFirstName();

  String getLasName();

  String getEmail();

  Set<AccountProjection> getAccounts();

  interface AccountProjection {
    Long getId();

    BigDecimal getBalance();

    CurrencyProjection getCurrency();
  }

  interface CurrencyProjection {
    Long getId();
  }
}

The important bit here is that the properties defined here exactly match properties in the aggregate root.

Then declare a query method in the repository.

interface CustomerRepository extends JpaRepository<Customer, Long> {
    Optional<CustomerWithAccountsProjection> findCustomerWithAccountsById(Long id);
}

The query execution engine creates proxy instances of that interface at runtime for each element returned and forwards calls to the exposed methods to the target object.

That's it. For other use cases, just declare a new interface and method in the repository.

With this approach, there's no need to pollute entity models with serialization-related annotations such as @JsonIgnore. Additionally, lazy-loaded associations would not be fetched unless declared in a projection.

If you need a more flexible API, I suggest GraphQL.

items.title: spring boot hibernate, how to avoid returning all the child objects?
items.body:
We have the following entities:

Customer, Account, Currency.

Customers can have many (set of) accounts, accounts have a currency. Thus in the DB, the accounts table has a customer_id, and also a currency_id FK.

When we read a customer record, hibernate always also reads both accounts table and currency table, even if we specify fetch = FetchType.LAZY.

  1. How can we get hibernate, in specific circumstances, to only query customers, and not their accounts?
  2. How can we get account to only return the currency_id, and not the whole currency record? we keep an in memory map of the currency table, for speed, its really on also in the DB for reporting.

customer entity:

@Entity
@NoArgsConstructor
@Getter
@Setter
public class Customer extends BaseEntity {

    @Id
    @SequenceGenerator(name= "customer_seq", sequenceName = "customer_seq", allocationSize = 1, initialValue = 100)
    @GeneratedValue(strategy = GenerationType.SEQUENCE,generator = "customer_seq")
    private Long id;

    private String firstName;
    private String lastName;
    private String email;
    private String password;

    @OneToMany(mappedBy = "customer", fetch = FetchType.LAZY)
    private Set<Account> accounts;
}

Strangely, for the Account object, we had to add @JsonIgnoreProperties({"hibernateLazyInitializer", "handler"}) to avoid the error:

No serializer found for class org.hibernate.proxy.pojo.bytebuddy.ByteBuddyInterceptor

but didn't have to add it for the other lazy loaded relationships.

@Entity
@NoArgsConstructor
@Getter
@Setter
public class Account  {

    @Id
    @SequenceGenerator(name= "account_seq", sequenceName = "account_seq", allocationSize = 1, initialValue = 100)
    @GeneratedValue(strategy = GenerationType.SEQUENCE,generator = "account_seq")
    private Long id;

    BigDecimal balance = new BigDecimal(0);

    @ManyToOne(optional = false)
    @JoinColumn(name = "customer_id", nullable = false)
    @JsonIgnore  // this is required to avoid recursion when returning customer json, which was unexpected because it should be lazy.
    Customer customer;

    @ManyToOne(optional = false, fetch = FetchType.LAZY)
    @JsonIgnoreProperties({"hibernateLazyInitializer", "handler"})
    Currency currency;

    }

This is how we are querying the customer:

RestController
class CustomerController {

    Logger log = LoggerFactory.getLogger(CustomerController.class);

    private final CustomerRepository repository;

    CustomerController(CustomerRepository repository) {
        this.repository = repository;
    }

    @GetMapping("/getCustomer")
    public Customer getCustomer(@RequestParam Long id) {
        return this.repository.findById(id).get();
    }
}

This is the resultant http response:

{
    "createdAt": null,
    "updatedAt": null,
    "version": 1,
    "id": 1,
    "firstName": null,
    "lastName": null,
    "email": "customer1@test.com",
    "password": "haha123",
    "phone": null,
    "accounts": [
        {
            "id": 1,
            "balance": 100.00,
            "currency": {
                "createdAt": null,
                "updatedAt": null,
                "version": 1,
                "id": 1,
                "iso": "GBP",
                "name": "Pound Sterling",
                "prefix": "£",
                "suffix": "",
                "decimalPlaces": 2,
                "visible": true
            }
        }
    ],
    "dob": null
}

I assume I would need to provide two different endpoints, or a parameter, and then somehow switch in the controller to pull back either only the customer, or the customer with accounts. Would I need to hardcode explicit SQL in custom service methods for this, or does spring/hibernate have something out of the box?

Also, when I query for accounts, I would ideally want it to return something like this:

{
    "accounts": [
        {
            "id": 1,
            "balance": 100.00,
            "currencyId": 1
        }
    ]
}

instead of this:

{
    "accounts": [
        {
            "id": 1,
            "balance": 100.00,
            "currency": {
                "createdAt": null,
                "updatedAt": null,
                "version": 1,
                "id": 1,
                "iso": "GBP",
                "name": "Pound Sterling",
                "prefix": "£",
                "suffix": "",
                "decimalPlaces": 2,
                "visible": true
            }
        }
    ]
}

answers.body_markdown:
You are not closing the `EntityManager` after the commit which means you keeping the connection open and therefore eventually run out of connections.

To fix this close the `EntityManager` after the commit.

answers.title: How to upLoad three (3) images on click per image using Glide
answers.body:
The issue in your code is you're using the same requestCode (RESULT_LOAD_IMG) for all three image views. When the user selects an image, the onActivityResult method is triggered with the same requestCode for all three image views, causing all of them to be updated.

To fix this issue, you need to use different request codes for each startActivityForResult call.

mImg.setOnClickListener(new View.OnClickListener() {
    @Override
    public void onClick(View v) {
        startImagePickerForResult(RESULT_LOAD_IMG);
    }
});
mImg1.setOnClickListener(new View.OnClickListener() {
    @Override
    public void onClick(View v) {
        startImagePickerForResult(RESULT_LOAD_IMG_1);
    }
});
mImg2.setOnClickListener(new View.OnClickListener() {
    @Override
    public void onClick(View v) {
        startImagePickerForResult(RESULT_LOAD_IMG_2);
    }
});

private void startImagePickerForResult(int requestCode) {
    Intent photoPickerIntent = new Intent(Intent.ACTION_PICK);
    photoPickerIntent.setType("image/*");
    startActivityForResult(photoPickerIntent, requestCode);
}


@Override
public void onActivityResult(int requestCode, int resultCode, @Nullable Intent data) {
    super.onActivityResult(requestCode, resultCode, data);
    if (resultCode == RESULT_OK && data != null) {
        final Uri imageUri = data.getData();

        switch (requestCode) {
            case RESULT_LOAD_IMG_1:
                Glide.with(getContext()).load(imageUri).into(mImg);
                break;
            case RESULT_LOAD_IMG_2:
                Glide.with(getContext()).load(imageUri).into(mImg1);
                break;
            case RESULT_LOAD_IMG_3:
                Glide.with(getContext()).load(imageUri).into(mImg2);
                break;
       }

    }

}

items.title: Spring Security ACL inhertiting on ACE level - alternatives
items.body:
I am working with spring security. I have the following simplified scenario:

class School{
    @OneToMany
    private Set<Module> modules;
}

class Module{
    @ManyToOne
    private School;
    @OneToMany
    private Set <Group> groups;
}

class Group{
    //...
}

I have a school, with modules and these modules have groups. When user a saves a new module, I want the module to inherit the ace entries of its school parent. Of those entries I just want the ones belonging to user a that manage read access. Meaning: If user a has read access for the parent school, he will gain read access for the module. I have quite a few of those filtered inheritance scenarios, also propagating deeper than just one level. I usually want only some aces of an acl to be inheriting. And I also need to toggle the inheriting status of single aces. I usually want to filter the aces of one acl for sid and/or permissions. What spring security is lacking for me is a flag 'inheriting' not only for each acl, but for each ace. Of course I can always manually copy the ace's of the parent that I want to be inheriting. But I have a pretty large entity oneToMany chain, meaning I need to go through the whole entity graph and also always from two sides: i.E. create module -> update ace's for all relevant users - create user -> update ace's of all relevant modules and so on.

Does anyone know a framework or library, that offers the functionality I need? Maybe also a library extending spring security acl? Thanks in advance!

EDIT: since asking for libraries is off topic, my updated question is: Does anyone know a way to implement that?

answers.body_markdown:
**EDIT**: This happened to me three times now, and on the third I came with a different solution that at least makes sense, so instead of adding another answer, I'll consolidate all answers here; if one sticks in future ocurrences, I'll update the answer again.

### ATTEMPT #3

Once again it plagued me, but this time I investigated a little more, by `grep`-ing for the old build number after cleaning up, both in the project dir and in `~/gradle`. It turns out the number isn't in the project when you clean, but crops up in the (generated intermediate asset) `BuildConfig.java`, and from there in all places. So my fix was:

- Clean project in Android Studio
- Quit Android Studio
- Ensure no gradle process is running (`ps -Af | grep gradle` should only show the grep, for example)
- Delete the `cache` directory inside `~/.gradle`
- Reopen Android Studio and generate the bundle

### ATTEMPT #2

So this happened a second time (and this time it wasn't updating even on the devices). Neither of the previous incantations worked, but what did it this time was going to `Edit Configurations...` on the `Run/Debug` dropdown, and switching from "Default APK" to "APK from app bundle".

That seems to have jolted things enough that the devices picked up the new manifest/version. 

Hope it works next time!

[![screenshot of Run/Debug configurations with the dropdown in question][1]][1]


  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/zooQv.png

### ATTEMPT #1

After trying everything under the sun, I did two things, not sure which one did the trick (strongly suspect the second, will try it in isolation next time)

1) On `Build`, `Select Build Variant...`, I switched from debug to release
2) Built a non-signed bundle (`Build`, `Build Bundle(s)/ APK(s)`, `Build Bundle(s)`).

The built bundle had the new version/manifest. From that point, building a signed bundle worked (suspiciously fast, but I guess it reused the last one and just signed it; app store accepted it as usual, whereas it was rejecting the others for having an already-used build number)

Had to revert "1" to properly debug on devices again (which I did not have to do last time, making me extra inclined to believe just 2 is needed.
answers.title: Android Studio is building old version via Generate Signed bundle / APK
answers.body:
EDIT: This happened to me three times now, and on the third I came with a different solution that at least makes sense, so instead of adding another answer, I'll consolidate all answers here; if one sticks in future ocurrences, I'll update the answer again.

ATTEMPT #3

Once again it plagued me, but this time I investigated a little more, by grep-ing for the old build number after cleaning up, both in the project dir and in ~/gradle. It turns out the number isn't in the project when you clean, but crops up in the (generated intermediate asset) BuildConfig.java, and from there in all places. So my fix was:

  • Clean project in Android Studio
  • Quit Android Studio
  • Ensure no gradle process is running (ps -Af | grep gradle should only show the grep, for example)
  • Delete the cache directory inside ~/.gradle
  • Reopen Android Studio and generate the bundle

ATTEMPT #2

So this happened a second time (and this time it wasn't updating even on the devices). Neither of the previous incantations worked, but what did it this time was going to Edit Configurations... on the Run/Debug dropdown, and switching from "Default APK" to "APK from app bundle".

That seems to have jolted things enough that the devices picked up the new manifest/version.

Hope it works next time!

ATTEMPT #1

After trying everything under the sun, I did two things, not sure which one did the trick (strongly suspect the second, will try it in isolation next time)

  1. On Build, Select Build Variant..., I switched from debug to release
  2. Built a non-signed bundle (Build, Build Bundle(s)/ APK(s), Build Bundle(s)).

The built bundle had the new version/manifest. From that point, building a signed bundle worked (suspiciously fast, but I guess it reused the last one and just signed it; app store accepted it as usual, whereas it was rejecting the others for having an already-used build number)

Had to revert "1" to properly debug on devices again (which I did not have to do last time, making me extra inclined to believe just 2 is needed.

items.title: Erro recorrente no VsCode desenvolvendo em Java
items.body:
Tenho enfrentado alguns erros recorrentes no VsCode com a linguagem Java, sempre apresentando erros sem sentido que, quando eu reinicio a IDE, acaba voltando ao normal. Normalmente esses erros têm alguma relação com a classe String. Erro dado nesse exato momento:

The type java.lang.invoke.MethodHandles$Lookup cannot be resolved. It is indirectly referenced from required type java.lang.StringJava(16777563)

Código trabalhado no momento:

public class Triangulos {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        int a = 1;
        int b = 4;
        int c = 5;
        String classificacao = "";
        boolean condicaoFormacao = a < b+c && b < a+c && c < a+b;
        boolean condicaoEquilatero = a == b && b == c;
        boolean condicaoIsosceles = (a == b && b != c) || (a == c && c != b) || (b == c && c != a);
        boolean condicaoEscaleno = (a != b && b != c);

        if(condicaoFormacao){
            System.out.print("É um triângulo");
            classificacao = "triangulo";
            // if(condicaoEquilatero){
            //     System.out.print(" e equilátero (lados iguais)");
            // }
        }
        else{
            System.out.println("Não é um triângulo");
            classificacao = "outra figura";
        }
        System.out.println("Classificação final: " + classificacao);
    }
}

Normalmente funciona com a reabertura do VsCode, porém gostaria de solucionar esse problema de uma vez por todas. Vou tentar reiniciar o computador para verificar se é solucionado.

answers.title: RETURNING syntax in PostgreSQL doesn't return SERIAL type attribute in Java
answers.body:
Try using PreparedStatement.RETURN_GENERATED_KEYS, which returns the generated key.

So remove the RETURNING clause from your query and add PreparedStatement.RETURN_GENERATED_KEYS as a second parameter to your prepareStatement() function.

String SQL_INSERT1 = "INSERT INTO events (title, start_time, end_time, description, creator_id, location, participants) VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?)";
PreparedStatement preparedStatement = conn.prepareStatement(SQL_INSERT1, PreparedStatement.RETURN_GENERATED_KEYS);

Then get the key generated using getGeneratedKeys() function.

preparedStatement.executeUpdate();
    
ResultSet res = preparedStatement.getGeneratedKeys();
if (res.next()) {
   int eventID = res.getInt(1);
}

items.body_markdown:
I have currently 4 services, each performs a specific task in the background on the text received from the user.
Which service is going to be started is decided depending on the text format. 
Let me give you two examples.


If I read text `December 9, 2023` I would start `DateType1Service`

If I read text `9/12/2023` I would start `DateType2Service`.


Since having both services could create conflict on the actions performed in the foreground, every time I need to check if other services are running, stop them and start the appropriate service. That's what I meant with "switch" in the title of my question.

Please note that this approach doesn't go necessarily against the rule of "long-running executable in the background" of a Service definition since if texts of the same type are detected then the service is never stopped, unless the system decide to kill it.

Now this architecture of having distinct services is of course great for code-readability but wouldn't be overall a better solution (performance is the main focus) to put everything inside one single service instead of having distinct services?

answers.title: Spring Boot Issue using MapStruct
answers.body:
Probably you didn't have configured well:

apart from dependency:

    <dependency>
        <groupId>org.mapstruct</groupId>
        <artifactId>mapstruct</artifactId>
        <version>${org.mapstruct.version}</version>
    </dependency>

you need to configure also the maven-compiler-plugin

<plugin>
     <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
     <artifactId>maven-compiler-plugin</artifactId>
     <version>3.8.0</version>
     <configuration>
         <annotationProcessorPaths>
             <path>
                 <groupId>org.mapstruct</groupId>
                 <artifactId>mapstruct-processor</artifactId>
                 <version>${org.mapstruct.version}</version>
             </path>
             <path>
                 <groupId>org.projectlombok</groupId>
                 <artifactId>lombok</artifactId>
                 <version>${lombok.version}</version>
             </path>
             <dependency>
                 <groupId>org.projectlombok</groupId>
                 <artifactId>lombok-mapstruct-binding</artifactId>
                 <version>0.2.0</version>
             </dependency>
         </annotationProcessorPaths>
         <compilerArgs>
             <compilerArg>
                 -Amapstruct.defaultComponentModel=spring
             </compilerArg>
         </compilerArgs>
     </configuration>
</plugin>

check this Step-By-Step tutorial: springframework.guru/mapstruct

answers.body_markdown:
For those who wanted to check if you are using the correct appPackage and appActivity, launch this via terminal or cmd.

If this adb command launches your APK file on your real device or emulator then that means [appPackage & appActivity] is valid. Play with Activity names or Packages until you hit the right values.

adb shell am start -W -n ***package_name***/***expected_activity_name*** -S -a android.intent.action.MAIN -c android.intent.category.LAUNCHER -f 0x10200000
answers.title: Appium unknow error: An unknown server-side error occurred while processing the command. Original error: 'app' option is required for reinstall
answers.body:
For those who wanted to check if you are using the correct appPackage and appActivity, launch this via terminal or cmd.

If this adb command launches your APK file on your real device or emulator then that means [appPackage & appActivity] is valid. Play with Activity names or Packages until you hit the right values.

adb shell am start -W -n package_name/expected_activity_name -S -a android.intent.action.MAIN -c android.intent.category.LAUNCHER -f 0x10200000

1. Plug in your Android device and launch the application

answers.body_markdown:
I fixed the issue!

All i had to do was to add JDK to Eclipse. It can be found here:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/13635563/setting-jdk-in-eclipse

Right click your project > properties
Select “Java Build Path” on left, then “JRE System Library”, click Edit…
Select "Workspace Default JRE"
Click "Installed JREs"
If you see JRE you want in the list select it (selecting a JDK is OK too)
If not, click Search…, navigate to Computer > Windows C: > Program Files > Java, then click OK
Now you should see all installed JREs, select the one you want
Click OK/Finish a million times

Instead of JRE i selected JDK folder and the app launched.


Thank you all!

comments.body_markdown: Not really related to your problem, nonetheless, note that controller classes no longer need to implement interface [Initializable](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/javafx/api/javafx/fxml/Initializable.html). You should write a `void initialize()` method, i.e. a method named `initialize` that takes no parameters and does not return a value. This method is invoked via [reflection](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/reflect/) by the JavaFX infrastructure.

Use this method to create a mighty alert dialog and pass arguments with ease via a method:

Helper method:

public static Stage createFxmlDialog(
        String title,
        boolean dialogIsModal,
        boolean dialogIsResizeable,
        URL absoluteFxmlFileUrl,
        Dimension2D sceneSize,
        @SuppressWarnings("rawtypes") Consumer initMethodOfController,
        Runnable callbackOnDialogClose)
        throws IOException {

    FXMLLoader loader = new FXMLLoader(absoluteFxmlFileUrl);
    Parent root = loader.load(); // this calls the constructor and after that initialize from jfx()
    Object viewController = loader.getController();
    Scene scene = sceneSize == null ? new Scene(root) : new Scene(root, sceneSize.getWidth(), sceneSize.getHeight());

    Stage stage = new Stage();
    stage.setTitle(title);
    stage.initModality(dialogIsModal ? Modality.APPLICATION_MODAL : Modality.NONE);
    stage.setResizable(dialogIsResizeable);
    stage.setScene(scene);
    stage.setOnHidden(event -> {
        event.consume();
        if (callbackOnDialogClose != null) {
            callbackOnDialogClose.run();
        }
        stage.close();
    });

    if (initMethodOfController != null) {
        //noinspection unchecked
        initMethodOfController.accept(viewController);
    }
    return stage;
}

StaffInfoController.java

package Controller;

import static Controller.HomeController.user;
import static Controller.HomeController.pass;
import Entitas.Pegawai;
import DBHelper.DBHelper;
import java.net.URL;
import java.sql.Connection;

import java.sql.ResultSet;
import java.sql.SQLException;

import javafx.fxml.FXML;
import javafx.fxml.Initializable;
import javafx.scene.control.Label;

public class StaffInfoController implements Initializable {

    @FXML
    private Label lblGaji;

    @FXML
    private Label lblIdPegawai;

    @FXML
    private Label lblJabatan;

    @FXML
    private Label lblNama;

    @FXML
    private Label lblStatus;

    @Override
    public void initialize(URL url, ResourceBundle rc) {
        try {
            showBiodata();
        }
        catch (SQLException ex) {
            Logger.getLogger(StaffInfoController.class.getName()).log(Level.SEVERE, null, ex);
        }
    }

    public void showBiodata() throws SQLException {
        Connection conn = DBHelper.getConnection();
        String sql = "SELECT * FROM pegawai WHERE username = '" + user + "' AND password_pegawai = '" + pass + "'";
        Statement st;
        ResultSet rs;
        st = conn.createStatement();
        rs = st.executeQuery(sql);
        if (rs.next()) {
            lblGaji.setText(String.format("%d", rs.getLong("gaji")));
            lblIdPegawai.setText(rs.getString("id_pegawai"));
            lblJabatan.setText(rs.getString("jabatan"));
            lblNama.setText(rs.getString("nama_pegawai"));
            lblStatus.setText(rs.getString("status_pegawai"));
        }
    }
}

HomeController.java

package Controller;

import DBHelper.DBHelper;
import AlertHelper.AlertHelper;
import java.io.IOException;
import java.sql.Connection;
import java.sql.PreparedStatement;
import java.sql.ResultSet;
import java.sql.SQLException;
import javafx.scene.control.Alert;
import javafx.event.ActionEvent;
import javafx.fxml.FXML;
import javafx.fxml.FXMLLoader;
import javafx.scene.Parent;
import javafx.scene.Scene;
import javafx.scene.control.Button;
import javafx.scene.control.Hyperlink;
import javafx.scene.control.PasswordField;
import javafx.scene.control.TextField;
import javafx.stage.Stage;

public class HomeController {

    @FXML
    private Hyperlink btnBuatAkun;

    @FXML
    private Button btnLogin;

    @FXML
    private PasswordField pfPassword;

    @FXML
    private TextField tfUsername;

    public static String user;
    public static String pass;

    @FXML
    public void gantiScene(ActionEvent event) throws IOException {
        user = tfUsername.getText();
        pass = pfPassword.getText();
        if (validateLogin(user, pass, "pegawai")) {
            AlertHelper.showAlert(Alert.AlertType.INFORMATION,
                                  "Login berhasil",
                                  "Login Pegawai Telah Berhasil");
            FXMLLoader loader = new FXMLLoader(getClass().getResource("/FXMLCol/Pegawai.fxml"));
            Parent root = loader.load();
            Stage stage = (Stage) btnLogin.getScene().getWindow();
            stage.setScene(new Scene(root));
        }
        else if (validateLogin(user, pass, "pelanggan")) {
            AlertHelper.showAlert(Alert.AlertType.INFORMATION,
                                  "Login Berhasil",
                                  "Login Username : " + user + " berhasil");
        }
        else {
            AlertHelper.showAlert(Alert.AlertType.ERROR,
                                  "Login Gagal",
                                  "Silahkan check username dan password lebih teliti");
            pfPassword.clear();
        }
    }

    @FXML
    void keBuatAkun(ActionEvent event) throws IOException {
        AlertHelper.showAlert(Alert.AlertType.WARNING,
                              "Konfirmasi",
                              " Anda akan dialihkan ke arah pembuatan akun");
        FXMLLoader loader = new FXMLLoader(getClass().getResource("/FXMLCol/Pegawai.fxml"));
        Parent root = loader.load();
        Stage stage = (Stage) btnBuatAkun.getScene().getWindow();
        stage.setScene(new Scene(root));
    }

    public static boolean validateLogin(String username, String password, String entitas) {
        String query;
        if (entitas.equals("pelanggan")) {
            query = "SELECT * FROM `pelanggan` WHERE username = ?  AND password_pelanggan = ? ";
        }
        else {
            query = "SELECT * FROM `pegawai` WHERE username = ?  AND password_pegawai = ? ";
        }
        try (Connection connection = DBHelper.getConnection()) {
            try (PreparedStatement preparedStatement = connection.prepareStatement(query)) {
                preparedStatement.setString(1, username);
                preparedStatement.setString(2, password);
                try (ResultSet resultSet = preparedStatement.executeQuery()) {
                    return resultSet.next();
                }
            }
        }
        catch (SQLException e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
            return false;
        }
    }
}

answers.title: How to add external css/js files in vertx
answers.body:
Back in Vert.x 2 time there was simple example how to do this:

import org.vertx.java.core.Handler;
import org.vertx.java.core.http.HttpServerRequest;
import org.vertx.java.platform.Verticle;

public class Server extends Verticle {
  public void start() {
      vertx.createHttpServer().requestHandler(new Handler<HttpServerRequest>() {
          public void handle(HttpServerRequest req) {
              String file = req.path().equals("/") ? "index.html" : req.path();
              req.response().sendFile("webroot/" + file);
          }
      }).listen(8080);
  }
}

See here: http://vertx.io/vertx2/ (Java tab)

Mind the disclaimer ;)

  • In a real production web-server you would want to do some checking of the path to ensure files aren't served from outside the webroot!

answers.title: Can and should a Maven POM specify if it requires Maven 3 or newer?
answers.body:
Yes you can and you should. Some Maven plugins requires Maven 3 or newer.

Use the maven-enforcer-plugin by adding the following to your pom.xml:

<build>
  <plugins>
    <plugin>
      <inherited>true</inherited>
      <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
      <artifactId>maven-enforcer-plugin</artifactId>
      <version>3.4.1</version>
        <executions>
          <execution>
            <id>enforce-maven-version</id>
            <goals>
              <goal>enforce</goal>
            </goals>
            <configuration>
              <rules>
                <requireMavenVersion>
                  <version>3.8.5</version>
                </requireMavenVersion>                
              </rules>
              <fail>true</fail>
            </configuration>
          </execution>
       </executions>
     </plugin>
  </plugins>
</build>

comments.body_markdown: Be mindful of including links as they can die... And note there was already another answer that includes the relevant snippet.
comments.body: Be mindful of including links as they can die... And note there was already another answer that includes the relevant snippet.

answers.body_markdown:
The best thing you can do is to use Enforcer plugin. Here's an example:  
http://maven.apache.org/enforcer/enforcer-rules/requireMavenVersion.html

There is no out-of-the-box method in Maven itself for doing this. There is actually `prerequisites` tag but it doesn't work well, because children don't inherit it.
answers.title: Can and should a Maven POM specify if it requires Maven 3 or newer?
answers.body:
The best thing you can do is to use Enforcer plugin. Here's an example:
http://maven.apache.org/enforcer/enforcer-rules/requireMavenVersion.html

There is no out-of-the-box method in Maven itself for doing this. There is actually prerequisites tag but it doesn't work well, because children don't inherit it.

answers.title: Can and should a Maven POM specify if it requires Maven 3 or newer?
answers.body:
Another option is to use the prerequisites element in the pom, for example:

<project>
   ...
   <prerequisites>
       <maven>3.0.0</maven>
   </prerequisites>
   ...
</project>

As noted Michal Kalinowski's answer - this simple approach does not work so well for children projects.

For a summary of which approach will work best for you, see here: enforcing maven 3 - when to use maven enforcer plugin? when to use pom prerequisites element?

answers.title: Java SMTP Server classnotfoundexception
answers.body:
You are missing javax.activation.DataHandeler class in build classpath, that's why your build is failing. This class is a part of javax.activation-api, which you can find on maven central easily. Just include this jar to build classpath and you should be good to go. For instance, if you are using Maven:

<dependency>
    <groupId>javax.activation</groupId>
    <artifactId>javax.activation-api</artifactId>
    <version>1.2.0</version>
</dependency>

Or using Gradle groovy DSL:

implementation 'javax.activation:javax.activation-api:1.2.0'

answers.title: Write a program with while loop code in it to calculate the amount of exam scores enter by a user
answers.body:
the reason it is continuously printing that out is because the "Scanner" class that you are using does not pause for input.

I would suggest that you use a BufferedReader.

I assume that you need to ask the user to enter a value each time. So if you remove the text to solve the multiple display issue, the user wont be given the message.

I have attached a snippet of the code, with a BufferedReader that will solve your problem:

//This is the code I wrote.// 
import java.util.Scanner;
import java.io.*;
import java.io.BufferedReader;
import java.util.*;

public class Grade{
	public static void main(String[] args){
		int A_grades = 0;
		int B_grades = 0;
		int C_grades = 0;
		int D_grades = 0;
		int F_grades = 0;
		int count=0;
		try{
			//Scanner in = new Scanner(System.in);
			BufferedReader br = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(System.in) );
			System.out.println("Enter exam score as integer percentage in range 0 to 100 :");
			int score = Integer.parseInt(br.readLine());
			while(score>0){
				count++;
				if(score>=90 && score<=100)
					A_grades++;
				else if(score>=80 && score<=89)
					B_grades++;
				else if(score>=70 && score<=79)
					C_grades++;
				else if(score>=60 && score<=69)
					D_grades++;
				else if(score>=0 && score<=59)
					F_grades++;
				System.out.println("Enter exam score as integer percentage in range 0 to 100 :");
				score = Integer.parseInt(br.readLine());
			} //end while
		}catch(IOException ioe){}
		System.out.println("Total number of grades :"+ count);
		System.out.println("Total number of A grades :"+ A_grades);
		System.out.println("Total number of B grades :"+ B_grades);
		System.out.println("Total number of C grades :"+ C_grades);
		System.out.println("Total number of D grades :"+ D_grades);
		System.out.println("Total number of F grades :"+ F_grades);
	} // end main
} // end class

Hope this helps you and answers your question :)

Let me know of the outcome

 import java.util.Scanner;
public class grade

 while(score>0)

    else if(score>=80 && score<=89)

    else if(score>=70 && score<=79)

    else if(score>=60 && score<=69)

items.body:
I wrote a program for the following question in a task I'm doing.

"Write a program to read a list of exam scores given as integer percentages in the range 0 to 100. Display the total number of grades and the number of grades in each letter-grade category as follows: 90-100 is A, 80-89 is B, 70-79 is C, 60-69 is D, and 0-59 is F. Use negative score as a sentinel value to indicate the end of the input."

For Example, input: 98,87,86,85,85,78,73,72,72,70,66,63,50,-1

Output should be:

Total number of grades entered was 13

A's =1

B's=4

C's=5

D's=2

F's=1

//This is the code I wrote.// 
import java.util.Scanner;
public class grade
 {
public static void main(String[] args)
 {
        int A_grades = 0;
        int B_grades = 0;
        int C_grades = 0;
        int D_grades = 0;
        int F_grades = 0;
        int count=0;
        Scanner in = new Scanner(System.in);
        System.out.println("Enter exam score as integer percentage in range 0 to 100 :");
        int score = in.nextInt();
 while(score>0)
 {
       count++;
 if(score>=90 && score<=100)
        A_grades++;
    else if(score>=80 && score<=89)
        B_grades++;
    else if(score>=70 && score<=79)
        C_grades++;
    else if(score>=60 && score<=69)
        D_grades++;
    else if(score>=0 && score<=59)
        F_grades++;
    System.out.println("Enter exam score as integer percentage in range 0 to 100 :");
 score = in.nextInt();
 } //end while
 System.out.println("Total number of grades :"+ count);
 System.out.println("Total number of A grades :"+ A_grades);
 System.out.println("Total number of B grades :"+ B_grades);
 System.out.println("Total number of C grades :"+ C_grades);
 System.out.println("Total number of D grades :"+ D_grades);
 System.out.println("Total number of F grades :"+ F_grades);
 } // end main
 } // end class

Below is the Output of the program.

Enter exam score as integer percentage in range 0 to 100 :

88 98 78 68 55 45 -1

Enter exam score as integer percentage in range 0 to 100 :

Enter exam score as integer percentage in range 0 to 100 :

Enter exam score as integer percentage in range 0 to 100 :

Enter exam score as integer percentage in range 0 to 100 :

Enter exam score as integer percentage in range 0 to 100 :

Enter exam score as integer percentage in range 0 to 100 :

Total number of grades :6

Total number of A grades :1

Total number of B grades :1

Total number of C grades :1

Total number of D grades :1

Total number of F grades :2

In the output it keeps repeating "Enter exam score as integer percentage in range 0 to 100 :"

How can I write the code to only show it once?

answers.body_markdown:
It's a [known bug][1] that occurs eventually for me associated to *Onedrive* backup. For me set `"Always keep on this device"` on in *OneDrive* doesn't solve it. 

I also noticed that this event is intermittent and probabilistic, being especially common in small and rapid source changes.

While the *JetBrains* team doesn't fix this problem, I simply pause the *OneDrive* sync in adjustments (gear icon) and few minutes later I resume it. It's a kind of trick, but it works and  it's fast. 

**Update**: Neither when I pause *OneDrive* works in all situations. I try everything, include invalidate caches. When I take out the folder from *OneDrive* it works. I will update it here if the problem returns.

  [1]: https://github.com/gradle/gradle/issues/22002
answers.title: Gradle - "Changes are not tracked, unable determine incremental changes."
answers.body:
It's a known bug that occurs eventually for me associated to Onedrive backup. For me set "Always keep on this device" on in OneDrive doesn't solve it.

I also noticed that this event is intermittent and probabilistic, being especially common in small and rapid source changes.

While the JetBrains team doesn't fix this problem, I simply pause the OneDrive sync in adjustments (gear icon) and few minutes later I resume it. It's a kind of trick, but it works and it's fast.

Update: Neither when I pause OneDrive works in all situations. I try everything, include invalidate caches. When I take out the folder from OneDrive it works. I will update it here if the problem returns.

answers.body_markdown:
You most likely need a 64 bit OS and a 64-bit Java install.  The release notes for OpenCyc state:

Note the release notes (that you linked to!) state:

    OpenCyc requires 3G RAM under 64bit and about 1G of disk space.
    Running OpenCyc under 32bit is no longer supported.

So, while the suggested change to the BAT file *might* work, it is unlikely that running Cyc with half<sup>1</sup> the *minimum* recommended heap size is going to to be pleasant.

-----------------

<sup>1 - The maximum Java heap size that you can expect to work on a 32 bit Windows platform is 1.5 to 1.8 GB ... for reasons due to the architecture of Windows.</sup>
answers.title: Invalid initial heap size: -Xms5g

Note the release notes (that you linked to!) state:

Running OpenCyc under 32bit is no longer supported.

So, while the suggested change to the BAT file might work, it is unlikely that running Cyc with half1 the minimum recommended heap size is going to to be pleasant.

1 - The maximum Java heap size that you can expect to work on a 32 bit Windows platform is 1.5 to 1.8 GB ... for reasons due to the architecture of Windows.

<br/>Add `ch=(ch+1)%5;` in `onClick`.

Declare ch as int type and initialize with 0.
Add ch=(ch+1)%5; in onClick.

@Component
public class LoggingFilter implements GlobalFilter {

    Logger logger = Logger.getLogger(LoggingFilter.class.getName());

    @Override
    public Mono<Void> filter(ServerWebExchange exchange, GatewayFilterChain chain) {
        ServerHttpRequest request = exchange.getRequest();
        String url = request.getURI().toString();
        logger.info("Request coming: URL - " + url);

        String countryName = request.getHeaders().getFirst("country");
        if (countryName != null && countryName.equals("US")) {
            throw new ResponseStatusException(HttpStatus.FORBIDDEN, "Country Not Allowed");
        }

        return chain.filter(exchange);
    }
}
