answers.title: Gradle error - java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/gradle/internal/hash/HashUtil
answers.body:
It looks like it's coming from https://github.com/kordamp/kordamp-gradle-plugins/blob/master/plugins/base-gradle-plugin/src/main/groovy/org/kordamp/gradle/util/Cache.groovy

This commit removes the reference for later versions of Gradle:

https://github.com/kordamp/kordamp-gradle-plugins/commit/b53171c9ecc61c40479e9d9044d4419b785bdc3e#diff-fe302b433f2713f6834e849752ebfbf8f326e6bf79385448e11bb34bfa5dd253L23

And the documentation is here https://kordamp.org/kordamp-gradle-plugins/

Check your build for kordamp:

dependencies {
  classpath 'org.kordamp.gradle:settings-gradle-plugin:0.45.0'
  classpath "org.kordamp.gradle:java-project-gradle-plugin:0.45.0"
}

And make sure it has 0.46.0 or later.

answers.body_markdown:
I had the same issue. 

After referring to this https://github.com/kordamp/kordamp-gradle-plugins/issues/489, I updated the `gradle-wrapper.properties` to use the compatible version `(6.9.1)` of gradle for Java 11 which fixed the issue.

    distributionUrl=https\://services.gradle.org/distributions/gradle-6.9.1-bin.zip

You can try by increasing height of detail band and if that doesn't work you can add one more detail, one for each sub-report.

answers.title: Jasperreports multiple subreports overlapping

You can try by increasing height of detail band and if that doesn't work you can add one more detail, one for each sub-report.

comments.body_markdown: In practice, when writing applications, you will almost never want to round a number to two decimal places.  For displaying currency, just do `System.out.println(NumberFormat.getCurrencyInstance().format(n));`.  If it’s not currency, you can just do `System.out.printf("%,.2f%n", n);`.  This allows the actual double value to retain high precision, even if you choose to *display* it with less precision.
comments.body: In practice, when writing applications, you will almost never want to round a number to two decimal places. For displaying currency, just do System.out.println(NumberFormat.getCurrencyInstance().format‌​(n));. If it’s not currency, you can just do System.out.printf("%,.2f%n", n);. This allows the actual double value to retain high precision, even if you choose to display it with less precision.

comments.body_markdown: Regardless of the differences, what they have in common is that in general they mostly don't work. See my answer in the duplicate for proof.
comments.body: Regardless of the differences, what they have in common is that in general they mostly don't work. See my answer in the duplicate for proof.

comments.body_markdown: No you won't. You will get whatever approximation to 123.46 is available in binary.
comments.body: No you won't. You will get whatever approximation to 123.46 is available in binary.

answers.body_markdown:
In the first approach:

```
n *= 100;        // Multiply by 100
n = Math.round(n); // Round to the nearest whole number
n = n / 100;      // Divide by 100
```
Here, the multiplication and rounding operations introduce a bit of [imprecision][1] due to the nature of [floating-point][2] arithmetic. When you round 123.4567 multiplied by 100, you get 12346.0. After dividing by 100, you get 123.46.

In the second approach:

```
System.out.println(Math.round(o * 100) / 100);
```
Here, you're rounding 123.4567 * 100, which results in 12346. When you then divide by 100, you get 123.0.

The key difference is that in the first approach, you perform the rounding after the multiplication and then the division, while in the second approach, you round the result of the multiplication and immediately divide it.

If you want the second approach to produce a result similar to the first approach, you should cast the result of the rounding operation to double before the division:

```
System.out.println((double) Math.round(o * 100) / 100);
```
This ensures that the division is done with floating-point precision, and you'll get 123.46 as the result.


  [1]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floating-point_arithmetic#Accuracy_problems
  [2]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floating-point_arithmetic
answers.title: Confused with variable types and Math.round
answers.body:
In the first approach:

n *= 100;        // Multiply by 100
n = Math.round(n); // Round to the nearest whole number
n = n / 100;      // Divide by 100

Here, the multiplication and rounding operations introduce a bit of imprecision due to the nature of floating-point arithmetic. When you round 123.4567 multiplied by 100, you get 12346.0. After dividing by 100, you get 123.46.

In the second approach:

System.out.println(Math.round(o * 100) / 100);

Here, you're rounding 123.4567 * 100, which results in 12346. When you then divide by 100, you get 123.0.

The key difference is that in the first approach, you perform the rounding after the multiplication and then the division, while in the second approach, you round the result of the multiplication and immediately divide it.

If you want the second approach to produce a result similar to the first approach, you should cast the result of the rounding operation to double before the division:

System.out.println((double) Math.round(o * 100) / 100);

This ensures that the division is done with floating-point precision, and you'll get 123.46 as the result.

answers.body_markdown:
You're missing two important things:

* This isn't _at all_ how you should deal with rounding.
* Nevertheless you may still be interested in an answer to your question. Which is: `/` means different things depending on context.

## `/` means different things

The key thing you're missing is that `/` means __2 different things in java__; context determines which of the 2 you get. In your first and second snippets, the `/` mean different things.

In the first and third, it means 'double division'. In the second, it means 'integer division'.

These 2 things are as different as guns and grandmas. Consider how `+` means __completely__ different things. Given `a + b`, well:

```
String a = "Hello";
String b = "World";
String c = a + b; // means string concatenation
```

```
int a = 5;
int b = 7;
int c = a + b; // means integer addition
```


You should consider `/` to be the same way.

In general __all java math operations are homogenous__. Meaning, java knows how to add an 'int' to an 'int' but cannot deal with the situation when the two arguments aren't of the same type. To 'fix' that, you will have to convert one of the two sides to be the same type as the other side. To make things a bit complicated, javac itself will _assume_ you meant to do just that and will convert one of them for you, __if__ it can: The rulebook states that java will only apply widening conversions - once that are generally considered lossless. For example, converting an int to a double is considered lossless. Converting an int to a short is not (a `short` can contain fewer values than `int` can).

Given:

```
int a = 11;
int b = 10;
double c = a / b;
System.out.println(c);
```

You might think that prints "1.1". __It will not__. Try it - run that. It'll print simply '1'.

That's because That slash there __means integer division__: Because both of its arguments are of type `int`, int division is what it means. The fact that you then assign the result of this to a variable of type `double` is not relevant to this determination. So, `a / b` is integer division, in integer division, all remainder is just lopped off (so, rounding down for positive numbers but rounding up for negative numbers, -5.5 becomes -5), producing just 1. This is then assigned to a `double` which requires conversion. Because that is 'widening', java injects the cast for you silently, there is no need to explicitly write it, and `c` is now 1.0.

The same is happening your code: The second snippet is dividing an integer by an integer (Because the return type of the `round` method in the `Math` class is `int`), thus, you get integer math.

When you use `/` and the operands are of mixed types, one of type `double` and the other of `int`, java will silently widening-convert the int to a double, so that just 'works':

```
double x = 11.0;
int y = 10;
double z = x / y;
System.out.println(z); // really will print '1.1'
```

Hence why a cast can be necessary:

```
int x = 11;
int y = 10;
double z = (double) x / y;
System.out.println(z); // really will print '1.1'
```

Here the `/` expression's left hand side is the expression `(double) x` which is of type `double`, the RHS is of type `int`, so that's not possible without conversion - but `int` can be silently converted to `double` so java compiles that as if you wrote: `(double) x / (double) y` which is double division, and that whole expression is of type double, so can be assigned verbatim to `z`.

## .. but don't do any of this

doubles are imprecise. In weird ways. If I ask you to write the result of 1 divided by 3 on a small piece of paper __you cannot do this__ - you write 0.33333 and run out of room.

Computers are the same way: They have limited space (64 bit, for `double`), and store decimals and not ratios (you can't write "1 / 3" in this system, only "0.3333"). Except, computers don't use decimal, they use binary.

The reason "1 / 10" 'works' (It's 0.1, no infinite sequence of digits) is because the divisors of 10 are 2 and 5, so any divisor that can be expressed solely as multiplying any number of 2s and 5s together 'works' (`10 = 2 * 5` - that works), and anything else won't.

In binary, it's just multiples of 2.

__This means 0.1 is not a double and causes rounding errors__. Try it! Write a java file that just does this:

```
double v = 0.0;
for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) v += 0.1;
System.out.println(1.0 == v);
```

And you will marvel! __Because that prints `false`__ and that _seems_ incorrect. It's 'correct' in the same sense that if I ask you to write 1/3 on a piece of paper three times and I _then_ ask you to tell me the sum of those 3 pieces of paper, you won't tell me 1. No, you'd tell me '0.999999'. Which is very close to, but not quite equal to, 1.0.

Hence, __you cannot think of `double` in this way__ - they cannot be used to hold exactly 'some number rounded to 2 decimals' because a thing that works in decimal (such as "0.10") may not work in binary.

Instead, you have 3 options:

### Atomicity

Whatever you're doing, find out if it has a workable atomic unit and just use those. For example, if doing finances, don't store the price of an object that costs 4 bucks and 20 cents as `double price = 4.2;`. No, store it as `int priceInCents = 420`.

But, not everything has an atomic unit.

### Accept the error

Accept that slight rounding errors will occur. NEVER try to round a number itself, instead, when _printing it_, round then:

```
double v = 1.2345; // v's value is not quite 1.2345, but something very close.
System.out.printf("%.2f\n", v);
```

That prints 1.23. Because '%.2f' rounds to 2 digits. Don't round the value, ask the thing that prints to round.

### BigDecimal

Use java's BigDecimal class which represents decimal numbers to any precision you want. But, this does mean:

* It's very slow and hard to use.
* Memory requirements grow as your number gains digits.
* It __still__ cannot solve the 1 / 3 dilemma. That division will fail, unless you tell BigDecimal how to round it.

Generally BD is overkill. Don't use it unless you really, really know what you are doing.

## Sooo.. finance stuff?

Always use `long` to represent your finances (unless you really really know what you are doing and think BD is a better idea. It rarely is). No matter what happens, `double` is __never__ the correct data type for finance.

And, of course, represent atomics. So, cents for euros and dollas, yen for yen, satoshis for bitcoin, pennies for pounds, and so on.

answers.body_markdown:
`Math.round(double)` returns a `long`. If you divide that by an `int 100` the result remains a `long` (integer division). If you first assign the rounded value to a double `n` you get a floating point division.

You missed a double cast.

answers.body_markdown:
> _"... Is there a difference between the first and second approaches that I'm just not seeing? They should be identical algorithms, just compressed into one line. ..."_

It would appear they're the same expression; they're not.

In the first calculation, you're _[promoting](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se21/html/jls-5.html)_ the _[Math#round](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/21/docs/api/java.base/java/lang/Math.html#round(double))_ result to a _double_.

```java
n = Math.round(n * 100);
```

Whereas, in the second calculation, the result, a _long_, is then divided by an _integer_, _100_.\
Thus, only _"123"_ is printed.

> _"... Why is a cast needed when it's all in one line and not needed when in separate lines?"_

In _Java_, dividing two non-floating-point values, will result in the _[integer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integer)_ value; non-fractional.

Here is an example.

```java
out.println(100 / 3);
out.println(100 / 3d);
```

Output

```none
33
33.333333333333336
```

On a final note, it's worth mentioning, you can choose a rounding "mode", when utilizing the _[BigDecimal](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/21/docs/api/java.base/java/math/BigDecimal.html)_ class.\
Each mode is outlined in the _[RoundingMode](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/21/docs/api/java.base/java/math/RoundingMode.html)_ _JavaDoc_.

Here is an example.

```java
import static java.lang.System.out;
import static java.math.RoundingMode.*;
```

```java
BigDecimal d = new BigDecimal("123.4567");
out.println(d.setScale(2, CEILING));
out.println(d.setScale(2, DOWN));
out.println(d.setScale(2, FLOOR));
out.println(d.setScale(2, HALF_DOWN));
out.println(d.setScale(2, HALF_EVEN));
out.println(d.setScale(2, HALF_UP));
out.println(d.setScale(2, UP));
```

Output

```none
123.46
123.45
123.45
123.46
123.46
123.46
123.46
```

comments.body_markdown: _"Just, assigning a second node to the "first" field will be sufficient."_ That wouldn't be sufficient because the second node also points back to the first node (Java's `LinkedList` is a doubly-linked list). Also consider that if the first node is the **only** node, then it will also need to clear `last`. So, if you don't clear the link from the next node back to the first node, or don't clear `last` if it `first` is the only node, then you retain it longer than necessary (not to mention that you might have wrong behaviour, depending how those fields are used).

The reason here is simply that if you **only** assign the second node to `first`, then you still hold a reference to the original first node (through `prev` of the new first node, or through `last` of `LinkedList` itself), and thus the original first node (and its value) cannot be garbage collected, and that will remain the case until the list itself becomes eligible for GC.

comments.body_markdown: Suppose we have a 2 generation collector.  Suppose that the 1st node is in the old generation and the 2nd one is in the new generation.  And we remove both nodes one at a time.  The 1st node can only be collected by the old gen collector.  The 2nd node *could* be generated by the new gen collector ... unless it thinks there is a reference to it from the old generation.  So clearing the (potential) old -> new link via `f.next = null;` *may* allow the new gen collector to collect the 2nd node itself ... rather than tenuring it.  That's what "help GC" is referring to.

answers.body_markdown:
The removeFirst method in a LinkedList helps the garbage collector by unlinking the first node because it allows the memory occupied by the removed node to be eligible for garbage collection. In a linked list, each node contains data and a reference (or link) to the next node in the sequence.

When you remove the first node using removeFirst, the reference to the first node is severed, and there are no more references to that node from within the linked list. As a result, the node becomes unreachable from the rest of the program, and it can be considered as no longer needed. This makes the memory associated with the first node eligible for garbage collection.

Garbage collection is a process in programming languages with automatic memory management where the runtime system identifies and reclaims memory that is no longer in use by the program. By unlinking the first node and allowing it to be collected by the garbage collector, you free up memory resources, helping to prevent memory leaks and improving the overall efficiency of your program.

items.title: Why does the removeFirst method of a LinkedList help the garbage collector by unlinking the first node?
items.body:
The code below is a method that removes the first node from a linked list.

public E removeFirst() {
    final Node<E> f = first;
    if (f == null)
        throw new NoSuchElementException();
    return unlinkFirst(f);
}

private E unlinkFirst(Node<E> f) {
    // assert f == first && f != null;
    final E element = f.item;
    final Node<E> next = f.next;
    f.item = null;
    f.next = null; // help GC
    first = next;
    if (next == null)
        last = null;
    else
        next.prev = null;
    size--;
    modCount++;
    return element;
}

According to my understanding, unreferenced objects will be garbage collected. Therefore, it is unnecessary to unlink the first node. Just, assigning a second node to the "first" field will be sufficient.

How does the process of disconnecting the first node from the next node help the garbage collector?

answers.title: How to add local .jar file dependency to build.gradle file?
answers.body:
If you really need to take that .jar from a local directory,

Add next to your module gradle (Not the app gradle file):

repositories {
   flatDir {
       dirs("libs")
   }
}


dependencies {
   implementation("gson-2.2.4")
}

However, being a standard .jar in an actual maven repository, why don't you try this?

repositories {
   mavenCentral()
}
dependencies {
   implementation("com.google.code.gson:gson:2.2.4")
}

answers.title: How to add local .jar file dependency to build.gradle file?
answers.body:
The accepted answer is good, however, I would have needed various library configurations within my multi-project Gradle build to use the same 3rd-party Java library.

Adding '$rootProject.projectDir' to the 'dir' path element within my 'allprojects' closure meant each sub-project referenced the same 'libs' directory, and not a version local to that sub-project:

//gradle.build snippet
allprojects {
    ...

    repositories {
        //All sub-projects will now refer to the same 'libs' directory
        flatDir {
            dirs "$rootProject.projectDir/libs"
        }
        mavenCentral()
    }

    ...
}

EDIT by Quizzie: changed "${rootProject.projectDir}" to "$rootProject.projectDir" (works in the newest Gradle version).

answers.title: How to add local .jar file dependency to build.gradle file?
answers.body:
You can try reusing your local Maven repository for Gradle:

  • Install the jar into your local Maven repository:

    mvn install:install-file -Dfile=utility.jar -DgroupId=com.company -DartifactId=utility -Dversion=0.0.1 -Dpackaging=jar

  • Check that you have the jar installed into your ~/.m2/ local Maven repository

  • Enable your local Maven repository in your build.gradle file:

    repositories {
  mavenCentral()  
  mavenLocal()  
}

dependencies {  
  implementation ("com.company:utility:0.0.1")  
}
    • Now you should have the jar enabled for implementation in your project

answers.body_markdown:
**A solution for those using Kotlin DSL**

The solutions added so far are great for the OP, but can't be used with Kotlin DSL without first translating them. Here's an example of how I added a local .JAR to my build using Kotlin DSL:

    dependencies {
        compile(files("/path/to/file.jar"))
        testCompile(files("/path/to/file.jar"))
        testCompile("junit", "junit", "4.12")
    }

Remember that if you're using Windows, your backslashes will have to be escaped:

    ...
    compile(files("C:\\path\\to\\file.jar"))
    ...

And also remember that quotation marks have to be double quotes, not single quotes.

---

**Edit for 2020:**

Gradle updates have deprecated `compile` and `testCompile` in favor of `implementation` and `testImplementation`. So the above dependency block would look like this for current Gradle versions:

    dependencies {
        implementation(files("/path/to/file.jar"))
        testImplementation(files("/path/to/file.jar"))
        testImplementation("junit", "junit", "4.12")
    }
answers.title: How to add local .jar file dependency to build.gradle file?
answers.body:
A solution for those using Kotlin DSL

The solutions added so far are great for the OP, but can't be used with Kotlin DSL without first translating them. Here's an example of how I added a local .JAR to my build using Kotlin DSL:

dependencies {
    compile(files("/path/to/file.jar"))
    testCompile(files("/path/to/file.jar"))
    testCompile("junit", "junit", "4.12")
}

Remember that if you're using Windows, your backslashes will have to be escaped:

...
compile(files("C:\\path\\to\\file.jar"))
...

And also remember that quotation marks have to be double quotes, not single quotes.

Edit for 2020:

Gradle updates have deprecated compile and testCompile in favor of implementation and testImplementation. So the above dependency block would look like this for current Gradle versions:

dependencies {
    implementation(files("/path/to/file.jar"))
    testImplementation(files("/path/to/file.jar"))
    testImplementation("junit", "junit", "4.12")
}

You can add jar doing:

For gradle just put following code in `build.gradle`:

    dependencies {
    ...
    compile fileTree(dir: 'lib', includes: ['suitetalk-*0.jar'])
    ...
    }
and for maven just follow steps:

For Intellij:
File->project structure->modules->dependency tab-> click on + sign-> jar and dependency->select jars you want to import-> ok-> apply(if visible)->ok

answers.body_markdown:
Some more ways to add local library files using [Kotlin DSL][1] (build.gradle.**kts**):

```kotlin
implementation(
    files(
        "libs/library-1.jar",
        "libs/library-2.jar",
        "$rootDir/foo/my-other-library.jar"
    )
)
```

```kotlin
implementation(
    fileTree("libs/") {
        // You can add as many include or exclude calls as you want
        include("*.jar")
        include("another-library.aar") // Some Android libraries are in AAR format
        exclude("bad-library.jar")
    }
)
```

```kotlin
implementation(
    fileTree(
        "dir" to "libs/",
        // Here, instead of repeating include or exclude, assign a list of paths
        "include" to "*.jar",
        "exclude" to listOf("bad-library-1.jar", "bad-library-2.jar")
    )
)
```

The above code assumes that the library files are in *libs/* directory of the module (by module I mean the directory where this build.gradle.kts is located).

You can use [Ant patterns](https://stackoverflow.com/a/86915/8583692) in `include`s and `exclude`s as shown above.

See [Gradle documentations](https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/declaring_dependencies.html#sub:file_dependencies) for more information about file dependencies.

Thanks to [this post](https://stackoverflow.com/a/56557241/8583692) for providing a helpful answer.


  [1]: https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/kotlin_dsl.html
answers.title: How to add local .jar file dependency to build.gradle file?
answers.body:
Some more ways to add local library files using Kotlin DSL (build.gradle.kts):

implementation(
    files(
        "libs/library-1.jar",
        "libs/library-2.jar",
        "$rootDir/foo/my-other-library.jar"
    )
)

implementation(
    fileTree("libs/") {
        // You can add as many include or exclude calls as you want
        include("*.jar")
        include("another-library.aar") // Some Android libraries are in AAR format
        exclude("bad-library.jar")
    }
)

implementation(
    fileTree(
        "dir" to "libs/",
        // Here, instead of repeating include or exclude, assign a list of paths
        "include" to "*.jar",
        "exclude" to listOf("bad-library-1.jar", "bad-library-2.jar")
    )
)

The above code assumes that the library files are in libs/ directory of the module (by module I mean the directory where this build.gradle.kts is located).

You can use Ant patterns in includes and excludes as shown above.

See Gradle documentations for more information about file dependencies.

Thanks to this post for providing a helpful answer.

answers.title: Gradle build without tests
answers.body:
Reference

To exclude any task from gradle use -x command-line option. See the below example

task compile << {
    println 'task compile'
}

task compileTest(dependsOn: compile) << {
    println 'compile test'
}

task runningTest(dependsOn: compileTest) << {
    println 'running test'
}
task dist(dependsOn:[runningTest, compileTest, compile]) << {
    println 'running distribution job'
}

Output of: gradle -q dist -x runningTest

task compile
compile test
running distribution job

Hope this would give you the basic

answers.title: Gradle build without tests
answers.body:
the different way to disable test tasks in the project is:

tasks.withType(Test) {enabled = false}

this behavior needed sometimes if you want to disable tests in one of a project(or the group of projects).

This way working for the all kind of test task, not just a java 'tests'. Also, this way is safe. Here's what I mean let's say: you have a set of projects in different languages: if we try to add this kind of record in main build.gradle:

 subprojects{
 .......
 tests.enabled=false
 .......
}

we will fail in a project when if we have no task called tests

answers.body_markdown:
Using `-x test` skip test execution but this also exclude test code compilation.

```
gradle build -x test 
```

In our case, we have a CI/CD process where one goal is compilation and next goal is testing (Build -> Test).

So, for our first `Build` goal we wanted to ensure that the whole project compiles well. For this we have used:

```
./gradlew build testClasses -x test
```

On the next goal we simply execute tests:

```
./gradlew test
```

answers.body_markdown:
In [The Java Plugin][1]:
```
$ gradle tasks

Build tasks
-----------
assemble - Assembles the outputs of this project.
build - Assembles and tests this project.
testClasses - Assembles test classes.

Verification tasks
------------------
test - Runs the unit tests.
```

Gradle build without test you have two options:
```
$ gradle assemble
$ gradle build -x test
```

but if you want compile test:
```
$ gradle assemble testClasses
$ gradle testClasses
```


  [1]: https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/java_plugin.html

answers.body_markdown:
Every action in gradle is a `task`, and so is `test`. And to exclude a `task` from gradle run, you can use the option `--exclude-task` or it's shorthand `-x` followed by the task name which needs to be excluded. Example:

    gradle build -x test



The `-x` option should be repeated for all the tasks that needs to be excluded.

If you have different tasks for different type of tests in your `build.gradle` file, then you need to skip all those tasks that executes test. Say you have a task `test` which executes unit-tests and a task `testFunctional` which executes functional-tests. In this case, you can exclude all tests like below:
  

    gradle build -x test -x testFunctional
answers.title: Gradle build without tests
answers.body:
Every action in gradle is a task, and so is test. And to exclude a task from gradle run, you can use the option --exclude-task or it's shorthand -x followed by the task name which needs to be excluded. Example:

gradle build -x test

The -x option should be repeated for all the tasks that needs to be excluded.

If you have different tasks for different type of tests in your build.gradle file, then you need to skip all those tasks that executes test. Say you have a task test which executes unit-tests and a task testFunctional which executes functional-tests. In this case, you can exclude all tests like below:

gradle build -x test -x testFunctional

answers.body_markdown:
This is a solution for Kotlin DSL (build.gradle.**kts**):

```kotlin
tasks.withType<Test> { // OR tasks.test {
    onlyIf {
        properties["areTestsEnabled"].toString().toBoolean()
    }
}
```

Execute the build like this:

```shell
./gradlew build
```

To include running tests:

```shell
./gradlew build -PareTestsEnabled=true
```

comments.body_markdown: The problem with this approach is ignoring intermediate results. Such tasks help to understand how quickly you can entangle, although there are no hundreds or thousands lines. Structure your intermediate data. Create collections of weeks which contain daily income, a kind of accounting conduit. When the data is arranged this way, the final balance will be easy to calculate. Same as weekly. Then, having all the data visually, you can easily see where it does not look like expected. This will help you in programming much more than trying to catch this imperative algorithm by the tail.

answers.title: Calculation error in java code (leet code)
answers.body:
Here is a much simpler way to do this:

    int totalMoney(int n) {
        int current_days=0;
        int total=0;
        int monday_deposit=0;
        int prev_deposit=0;

        while(current_days!=n){
            if(current_days%7==0){ // It is a Monday!!!
                monday_deposit+=1;
                prev_deposit=monday_deposit;
            } else{
                prev_deposit+=1;
            }
            total+=prev_deposit;
            current_days++;
        }

        return total;
    }

The core idea is to maintain the prev deposit on the basis of the days. I hope the code is self explanatory.

items.title: Calculation error in java code (leet code)
items.body:
QUESTION:- 'Hercy wants to save money for his first car. He puts money in the Leetcode bank every day.

He starts by putting in $1 on Monday, the first day. Every day from Tuesday to Sunday, he will put in $1 more than the day before. On every subsequent Monday, he will put in $1 more than the previous Monday. Given n, return the total amount of money he will have in the Leetcode bank at the end of the nth day.'

CODE :-

public class Practice {
    public static int weekCalc (int a , int n){
        // a - week count 
        //n - number of days 
        int c = (n/2)*(2*a + n - 1);
        return c;
    }

    public static int total (int n ){
        int sum = 0;
        if (n<=7){
            sum +=  weekCalc(1, n); 
        } else {
            int num = n/7;
            for (int i =1 ; i<= num; i++){
                sum +=  weekCalc(i, 7);
            }
            int d = n%7;
            sum += weekCalc(num +1, d);
        }
        return sum ;

    }
    public static void main (String args[]){
       int ans = total(5);
       System.out.println(ans);
    }
}

This is the Leetcode 1716. Leetcode bank problem . I tried solving it using sum of AP but there seems to be an error in the weekCalc function , it isn't giving me the correct output . Like for weekCalc (1,5) the output should be 15 but its giving me 12 . I have cross checked the code several times ; I know there are other methods to solve this question but why isn't this one working ??

comments.body_markdown: The fact you did need `Class.forName` is that you're using Tomcat, and automatic driverloading will have already run at the the time your WAR is loaded. That means drivers in the WAR are not subject to automatic driverloading, and you need to load it explicitly. That said, you shouldn't use `DriverManager` in a web application, you should use a `javax.sql.DataSource` implementation backed by a connection pool (Tomcat comes with one built-in, but there are also others).
comments.body: The fact you did need Class.forName is that you're using Tomcat, and automatic driverloading will have already run at the the time your WAR is loaded. That means drivers in the WAR are not subject to automatic driverloading, and you need to load it explicitly. items.title: IntelliJ Tomcat + PostgreSQL JDBC Connection Issue - java.sql.SQLException: No suitable driver found for jdbc:postgresql://localhost:5432/postgres
items.body:
[FIXED] UPD: Successfuly fixed. Importing the driver through maven and adding Class.forName() before creating Connection helped me ( although it was mentioned almost everywhere that the construct is considered deprecated since Java 8, apparently it has not lost its usefulness ). I hope my solution will help someone who finds himself in a similar situation.

I am learning to work with PostgreSQL and the Tomcat server. I haven't encountered such issues when working with MySQL, and there were no driver problems when using Eclipse (I added the driver to the server's classpath, and everything worked perfectly).

Now, when I'm attempting to run the most basic program for database operations (retrieving a pre-prepared list of books from my database), the following error occurs:

java.sql.SQLException: No suitable driver found for jdbc:postgresql://localhost:5432/postgres
    at java.sql/java.sql.DriverManager.getConnection(DriverManager.java:702)
    at java.sql/java.sql.DriverManager.getConnection(DriverManager.java:228)
    at com.ex.dynamicweb.DBHandler.getBooks(DBHandler.java:22)
    at com.ex.dynamicweb.HelloServlet.doGet(HelloServlet.java:23)
    at jakarta.servlet.http.HttpServlet.service(HttpServlet.java:564)
    at jakarta.servlet.http.HttpServlet.service(HttpServlet.java:658)
    at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.internalDoFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:205)
    at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.doFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:149)
    at org.apache.tomcat.websocket.server.WsFilter.doFilter(WsFilter.java:51)
    at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.internalDoFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:174)
    at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.doFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:149)
    at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardWrapperValve.invoke(StandardWrapperValve.java:167)
    at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardContextValve.invoke(StandardContextValve.java:90)
    at org.apache.catalina.authenticator.AuthenticatorBase.invoke(AuthenticatorBase.java:482)
    at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardHostValve.invoke(StandardHostValve.java:115)
    at org.apache.catalina.valves.ErrorReportValve.invoke(ErrorReportValve.java:93)
    at org.apache.catalina.valves.AbstractAccessLogValve.invoke(AbstractAccessLogValve.java:673)
    at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardEngineValve.invoke(StandardEngineValve.java:74)
    at org.apache.catalina.connector.CoyoteAdapter.service(CoyoteAdapter.java:340)
    at org.apache.coyote.http11.Http11Processor.service(Http11Processor.java:391)
    at org.apache.coyote.AbstractProcessorLight.process(AbstractProcessorLight.java:63)
    at org.apache.coyote.AbstractProtocol$ConnectionHandler.process(AbstractProtocol.java:896)
    at org.apache.tomcat.util.net.NioEndpoint$SocketProcessor.doRun(NioEndpoint.java:1744)
    at org.apache.tomcat.util.net.SocketProcessorBase.run(SocketProcessorBase.java:52)
    at org.apache.tomcat.util.threads.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1191)
    at org.apache.tomcat.util.threads.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:659)
    at org.apache.tomcat.util.threads.TaskThread$WrappingRunnable.run(TaskThread.java:61)
    at java.base/java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:834)

The issue is resolved solely by adding the JDBC driver to the tomcat/lib folder. However, are there any ways to automatically add this driver directly through the IDE? I tried changing Deployment, Artifacts (manually added the lib folder to WEB-INF in the exploded war), manually specified the path to the driver through libraries, imported JDBC Driver using maven, and added it to Modules - none of this helped solve my problem. Perhaps someone has encountered this?

JDBC Driver: 42.6.0 PostgreSQL: 16 Java: 11 Tomcat: 10.1.16 ( same problem 8.5.96 ) IntelliJ Ultimate 2023

I'm providing the code for my program as well as screenshots of the mentioned Artifacts/Modules/Libraries for reference:

idex.jsp

<%@ page contentType="text/html; charset=ISO-8859-1" pageEncoding="ISO-8859-1" %>
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
<title>Books</title>
</head>
<body>
<h1><%= "Hello World!" %>
</h1>
<br/>
<a href="hello-servlet">Hello Servlet</a>
</body>
</html>

HelloServlet.java

package com.ex.dynamicweb;

import java.io.*;

import jakarta.servlet.http.*;
import jakarta.servlet.annotation.*;

@WebServlet(name = "helloServlet", value = "/hello-servlet")
public class HelloServlet extends HttpServlet {
    private String message;

    public void init() {
        message = "Hello World!";
    }

    public void doGet(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response) throws IOException {
        response.setContentType("text/html");

        // Hello
        PrintWriter out = response.getWriter();
        out.println("<html><body>");
        out.println("<h1>" + message + "</h1>");
        for (String book : DBHandler.getBooks()) {
            out.print(book + "</br>");
        }
        out.println("</body></html>");
    }

    public void destroy() {
    }
}

DBHandler

package com.ex.dynamicweb;

import java.sql.Connection;
import java.sql.DriverManager;
import java.sql.ResultSet;
import java.sql.Statement;
import java.sql.SQLException;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

public class DBHandler {

    private static final String SELECT_ALL_FROM_LIBRARY = "SELECT * FROM library.books";

    public static List<String> getBooks() {
        List<String> result = new ArrayList<String>();
        String url = "jdbc:postgresql://localhost:5432/postgres";
        String user = "postgres";
        String password = "1234";

        try (Connection connection = DriverManager.getConnection(url,
                user, password)) {
            System.out.println("Java JDBC PostgreSQL Example");

            System.out.println("Connected to PostgreSQL database!");
            Statement statement = connection.createStatement();
            ResultSet resultSet = statement.executeQuery(SELECT_ALL_FROM_LIBRARY);
            while (resultSet.next()) {
                result.add(resultSet.getString("NAME") + "- id: " + resultSet.getString("ID"));
            }
        } catch (SQLException e) {
            System.out.println("Connection failure.");
            e.printStackTrace();
        }

        return result;
    }
}

If he happens to need exactly one of those bundles, it might have helped. I don't understand why he actually wants to do it this complicated, and I see no reason why one would do it that way. There's so much better approaches, true. It looks like he actually just wants a whole JRE in one zip archive. So why not create one? I usually run with jre1.8.0_231, repacked the .jar files (saves 50% space) and even runs down on WinXP.

comments.body_markdown: Some of the several JDK vendors provide a JRE edition of their products. One of those is [Temurin from Adoptium](https://adoptium.net/temurin/releases/) at the Eclipse Foundation. (Select “JRE” from *Package Type*.) Other vendors might include Amazon, IBM, Red Hat, Azul Systems, Oracle, SAP, BellSoft, and Microsoft. Read the licensing terms of each product you consider.

I'm trying to run an old software that requires JRE v.1.6.0 (32bit) at startup. I'd like to install the most recent, modern compatible and usable minimum runtime for the requirement. 

Since that doesn't seem possible, I opted for installing the old version of JRE (1.6.0) for which I couldn't find anything but the full JDK.
Since I only need the runtime, is it possible to extract and install only the JRE from the JDK package?

I tried installing the most recent JRE (64bit) but that didn't work-
I tried to extract with some third party .msi extraction tools, but nothing resulted in something usable.

I tried downloading a JRE package from [this](https://stackoverflow.com/a/23829062/20069957) excellent table, but Windows 11 won't allow me to run the installer since its not verified (getting the "This installation package could not be opened" error).

Any help would be appreciated.

answers.title: SecurityFilterChain - http.authorizeHttpRequests() not working. localhost redirected you too many times
answers.body:
.loginPage() javadoc says this:

...login page to redirect to if authentication is required...

With your endpoint /login served by controller, you enter redirects cycle. You can try next:

  1. Create MvcConfig class (customize it due to your own rules):
@Configuration
public class MvcConfig extends WebMvcConfigurationSupport {

    @Override
    public void addViewControllers(ViewControllerRegistry registry) {
        registry.addViewController("/login").setViewName("login");
    }

    @Override
    protected void addResourceHandlers(ResourceHandlerRegistry registry) {
        registry.addResourceHandler("/static/**").addResourceLocations("classpath:/static/");
    }
}
  1. Delete yor /login endpoint from controller.
  2. Test new configuration.

Hope it helps, feel free to give feedback for my answer.

comments.body_markdown: The OAEP padding size depends on the key size and message size on top of the OAEP parameters. The amount of padding is automatically extended to make the message and padding fit the key size. What Ebbe showed is the *minimum* amount of padding.
comments.body: The OAEP padding size depends on the key size and message size on top of the OAEP parameters. The amount of padding is automatically extended to make the message and padding fit the key size. What Ebbe showed is the minimum amount of padding.

answers.body_markdown:
What you describe is known as [Hybrid Encryption][1] and is a common way to get the speed of symmetric-key crypto systems combined with the benefits of the two keys of RSA. 


**As for the specifics:**

 
A 2048 bit RSA key allows for 256 bytes of which the OAEP padding takes **`42`** bytes, leaving around 214 bytes for encrypted data. An AES-256 key is 256 bits (32 bytes) long, so there is plenty of space for it.  


  [1]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybrid_cryptosystem
answers.title: RSA maximum message length with specific padding
answers.body:
What you describe is known as Hybrid Encryption and is a common way to get the speed of symmetric-key crypto systems combined with the benefits of the two keys of RSA.

As for the specifics:

A 2048 bit RSA key allows for 256 bytes of which the OAEP padding takes 42 bytes, leaving around 214 bytes for encrypted data. An AES-256 key is 256 bits (32 bytes) long, so there is plenty of space for it.

I'm trying to implement some encryption in my Java application.
The encryption should work as follows:

 1. Generate random n bits AES key
 2. Encrypt AES key using RSA public key
 3. Send encrypted AES key to server
 4. Encrypt data with AES key + send to server

I'm having trouble deciding what padding algorithm to use. I read `OAEPWithSHA-1AndMGF1Padding` is a good choice, but what is the maximum message length I can encrypt with this?

I need to know the exact maximum bytes my AES key can be to be encrypted using RSA with `OAEPWithSHA-1AndMGF1Padding`.

The length of the RSA key makes difference too. I will probably go for 2048 bits.

**TL;DR: How many bytes can I encrypt using a 2048 bits RSA key with `OAEPWithSHA-1AndMGF1Padding`?**

answers.body_markdown:
BEA-002616

Critical: Failed to listen on channel "channel" on listenAddress:port, failure count: fails1, failing for secs2 seconds, e3

Description

The server listener will retry the listen after a short delay.
Cause

The server got an exception while trying to accept client connections. It will try to backoff to aid recovery.

Action

The OS limit for the number of open file descriptor (FD limit) needs to be increased. Tune OS parameters that might help the server to accept more client connections (e.g. TCP accept back log).


Please check below link

http://modj.org/home/aktueles/bea-002616-failed-to-listen-on-channel-on-listenaddressport/a7e2db8254aee4603e4ecaf98a43e85e.html
answers.title: Oracle Weblogic Server: java.net.SocketException "Too many open files"
answers.body:
BEA-002616

Critical: Failed to listen on channel "channel" on listenAddress:port, failure count: fails1, failing for secs2 seconds, e3

Description

The server listener will retry the listen after a short delay. Cause

The server got an exception while trying to accept client connections. It will try to backoff to aid recovery.

Action

The OS limit for the number of open file descriptor (FD limit) needs to be increased. Tune OS parameters that might help the server to accept more client connections (e.g. TCP accept back log).

Please check below link

http://modj.org/home/aktueles/bea-002616-failed-to-listen-on-channel-on-listenaddressport/a7e2db8254aee4603e4ecaf98a43e85e.html

answers.body_markdown:
Oracle Fusion Middleware active uses file's descriptors on Unix-like OS. You should up open file descriptors limit for your user (user that startup WebLogic Server):

add into the file /etc/security/limits.conf followed information:

    weblogic soft nproc 32768
    weblogic hard nproc 32768
    weblogic soft nofile 32768
    weblogic hard nofile 32768

(weblogic is your user), than relogin with weblogic user and test open file descriptors limit:

    $ ulimit -n
answers.title: Oracle Weblogic Server: java.net.SocketException "Too many open files"
answers.body:
Oracle Fusion Middleware active uses file's descriptors on Unix-like OS. You should up open file descriptors limit for your user (user that startup WebLogic Server):

add into the file /etc/security/limits.conf followed information:

weblogic soft nproc 32768
weblogic hard nproc 32768
weblogic soft nofile 32768
weblogic hard nofile 32768

(weblogic is your user), than relogin with weblogic user and test open file descriptors limit:

$ ulimit -n

I get the following exception when loading the server with webservice calls:

    <2013-nov-19 kl 0:23 CET> <Critical> <Server> <BEA-002616> <Failed to listen on 
    channel "Default" on 10.39.21.109:28404, failure count: 1, failing for 0 seconds,
    java.net.SocketException: Too many open files (errno:24)>

The machine that is used is an HP-UX.

If I look at these files (using lsof) that the application has opened I can see that there is a webservice connection that hasn't been closed.

    java    19290 xxxx 2102u  IPv4 0xe00000038b2df680    0t2534      
    TCP u30427.xx.yy:63565->u30436.xx.yy:36693 (CLOSE_WAIT)

These connections increases over time and reaches the maximum allowed number of files, and hence, the ”Too many open files” is thrown.

The strange part is that if I use HTTP (without SSL) it works fine, however when using HTTPS/SSL I get this error.

Does anyone here have any clue of what I can do to solve this problem?

Thanks!
